Sentence: Significantly, the PRC produces the following OP pesticides, on the order of , tons/year (or more, - ): Pesticide Table If local production and consumption of pesticides in the PRC (estimated by Monsanto to be approximately US $ , ) remains at current levels, starting materials will also be in strong demand, especially for phosphorus trichloride.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Many others probably are produced in smaller quantities in China: Dimethoate (Dongguo) example, CH OH +

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, the phosphorus industry in China is capable of producing large quantities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nonetheless, at the time of the Sino-Soviet feud, as far as military chemistry is concerned, China was even more backward than the Soviet Union.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: We do not know what degree of technological competence and production levels in chemical manufacture existed in China before , especially during the times when economic data was considered "secret."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: By the s, however, China clearly has mastered many commercial methods of producing fine chemicals, including key precursors and intermediates that could be diverted to CW-agent manufacture.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If China has in fact destroyed its chemical weapons--and by its reported documentation to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) in The Hague, it has--the PRC did so at a time when it could produce nearly any of the known CW agents in mass quantities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: From an economic point of view, joining the CWC was for China a strategic decision to ensure that it's "pillar industry," namely chemical, would not be impeded by international export controls.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An optimistic assessment would be that Deng Xiaoping's policy to subordinate the military to a strong economy applies to the Chinese chemical industry as well.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The pessimist would note that, in the event of a major crisis, the PRC would have little trouble reconstituting a large chemical weapons arsenal within a relatively short time.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Perspectives on BW Official PRC histories of BW, justifiably, recount at length the experience of Japan's invasion of China, and the gruesome experiments conducted by Gen. Ishii Shiro and his Unit .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Allegations that the United States routinely conducted BW during the Korean war, however mendacious and insupportable, also seem to be accepted as fact by the PLA.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The book on BW printed by the PRC's National Defense Press, for example, extensively covers the issue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nonetheless, despite no reliable evidence of US complicity (and even recent proof that the Chinese themselves have colluded with North Korea to fabricate biological weapons), the charges are ingrained among senior Chinese leaders.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At the very least, this legend provides a historical starting point for the PLA's development of anti-BW defense measures and training.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: But with regard to future arms control agreements and intelligence assessments, the belief of the PRC that the United States employed biological weapons during the Korean war is significant.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese, who see even the Opium War of the s as having happened only yesterday, will be influenced by their interpretation of such historical events, no matter whether true or false.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China alleges the following US BW attacks in North Korea: While the United States was retreating south under attack by the united Sino- Korean Army, in December of the United States military disseminated smallpox against the Korean capital of Pyongyang, Hwanghae do, and other areas.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Similar conspiracy type of allegations seem to continue into the s. For example, the PLA may actually believe that unusual outbreaks of hemorrhagic fever that occurred in Kenya in , were in fact the results of US BW experiments, and makes similar insinuations concerning the Ebola virus outbreaks in Zaire.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: BW Offense Writings are scanty on Chinese CW capabilities and even more so on BW.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A PRC official from the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs assured me that China has no biological weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A book on the subject, with the imprimatur of Chi Haotian, states categorically that "China has never manufactured nor possessed biological weapons."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: According to its submitted Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BWC) declarations, the PRC has declared the following facilities as having a "national defensive biological warfare R&D program," and listed the following facilities: Dual Use/BW Defense Research Facilities ( ) Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Institute of Medical Biology, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC claims that no BL- (highest containment for extremely contagious and virulent organisms) laboratories exist, at least as far as BW-related research is concerned.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Little of the scientific literature that the PRC reports in its BWC declarations is worth noting except for public-health-related research on bioaerosols and reviews on staphylococcal toxins.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Allegations of BW Activity in Xinjiang Province Ken Alibek, formerly with the Soviet/Russian Biopreparat BW complex, suggests that an outbreak of hemorrhagic fever in Xinjiang Province near Lop Nor was the result of Chinese activity in BW research: Intelligence sources found evidence of two epidemics of hemorrhagic fever in this area in the late s, where these diseases were previously unknown.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Our analysts concluded that they were caused by an accident in a lab where Chinese scientists were weaponizing viral diseases.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Another source in Taiwan told me that he felt certain a BW facility of some sort did exist in Xinjiang Province, not far from the nuclear testing facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As for the allegations of the source of outbreaks in Xinjiang, we should be cautious because of the natural occurrence of Xinjiang hemorrhagic fever (HF) endemic to the area, a variant of Crimean-Congo HF of the bunyaviridae-type virus that occasionally strikes in northeastern China, and where a significant outbreak occurred in .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Given the poor track record of the BWC as it is currently implemented (or more accurately, is not being implemented), China probably is withholding much information about its BW research, although such research primarily may be defensive in nature.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Agricultural BW A newspaper in the United States intimated that the foot and mouth disease (FMD) outbreak in Taiwan could have been due to mainland Chinese sabotage.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A similar conclusion was also reached in the Taiwan agricultural community.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, Stock-Farming of Tendays [sic] (Nongmu Xunkan), September , writes: The outbreak of FMD in Taiwan was caused by the introduction of virus through either the smuggling of goods or related agricultural products.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It was finally determined by means of analysis in foreign research institute(s) that the FMD outbreak was absolutely the same as that in the mainland, thus proving that infection was brought into Taiwan from the PRC.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It was completely because of smuggling meat products across the boundary by smuggling that caused great economic losses to Taiwan amounting to one percent of ( )'s

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The few Chinese writings on the subject of BW preponderantly discuss the allegations of US use of BW during the Korean war.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, to foil the enemy's germ-laden, flying insects or plague-infested rats, the PLA handbook on BW even suggests how to use simple brooms and nets, and procedures for burying the offensive detritus.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: BW Defense in the PLA In keeping with the definition of BW as "public health in reverse," PRC writings on the subject treat the matter more in terms of infectious disease control, an approach that is standard everywhere.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As one would expect, considerable amount of research has been conducted in China on potential BW agents including tularemia, Q fever, plague, anthrax, West and Eastern Equine Encephalitis, psittacosis, among others.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some specialized equipment has also been fielded in some unspecified numbers to counter the threat of BW to PLA troops.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA Military Medicine and BW Defense

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The earliest semblance of routinized BW defense in the PLA were the sanitation/anti-plague units, formed during the involvement of the Chinese People's Volunteer Army in Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Building a more formal curriculum in BW defense, the PLA continued work in anti- plague research, and in delegations and students visited the Soviet Union for expertise in microbiology and infectious disease.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Changing Character of China s WMD Proliferation Activities Evan S. Medeiros Beginning in the early s, China's weapons proliferation activities emerged as an issue of growing concern for US policymakers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese companies in the last two decades have exported to several countries a variety of goods useful in building nuclear weapons, chemical weapons, and ballistic and cruise missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In some cases, China has provided critical materials, equipment, and technical assistance to nations who could not otherwise acquire these items for their weapons programs.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Most notably, China provided Pakistan with a basic nuclear weapon design and substantial assistance in fabricating weapons-grade nuclear material.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Moreover, China has provided some countries with production technologies, allowing these nations to indigenously build certain missile systems with little external assistance.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China's proliferation behavior over the last two decades has been highly egregious, it has also improved dramatically in recent years, especially since the mid- s.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese government has gradually signed onto a number of key nonproliferation treaties, such as the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty (NPT) and the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) and has developed internal bureaucratic and regulatory structures to carry out these commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This is not to say that China no longer engages in exports of proliferation concern to the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Rather, the nature of the China-proliferation problem is fundamentally different, and US nonproliferation policies on China should be changed accordingly.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This paper addresses one central question: What is the current scope of China's proliferation activities related to weapons of mass destruction (WMD), and how has it changed over the last years?

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Answering this question will help to establish the factual and conceptual basis for understanding the nature of the problem and determining viable options for US policy-makers in an effort to change Chinese behavior.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To evaluate the scope of Chinese proliferation activities, this paper considers three indicators: the geographic scope of China's WMD exports, the types of exports (e.g., weapon-specific or dual-use technologies) and their contribution to WMD programs, and the frequency of such transfers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These three indicators are applied to three case studies around which this paper is structured; the three case studies cover China nuclear exports, missile (ballistic and cruise) exports, and chemical exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The paper examines each of these case studies over a -year period to provide a historical perspective on the shifts and changes in the scope of China's WMD proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Drawing on this analytical framework, this paper argues that in the last two decades the overall scope of Chinese proliferation activities has declined across the board.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The geographic distribution of Chinese proliferation-relevant exports has narrowed from almost a dozen countries to three: Iran, Pakistan, and to a lesser extent North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The character of China's exports similarly narrowed from a broad range of nuclear materials and equipment (much of it unsafeguarded) and complete missile systems to exports of dual-use nuclear, missile, and chemical technologies today.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, during much of the s and s, China's nuclear and missile assistance directly contributed to the nuclear and missile programs in other countries; today such assistance is indirect, at best.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The frequency of such exports also appears to have declined to a dribble of dual-use items, albeit declining less than the scope or technical character of China's exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Despite this overall narrowing of China's WMD-related exports, further progress will be slow.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Significant policy differences between Washington and Beijing exist about controlling dual-use nuclear, chemical, and missile goods to Iran and Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These contrasting policies are based on profound differences between the respective foreign policy approaches of the United States and China to Iran and Pakistan, the utility of supply-side technology control regimes, China's ability to implement and enforce its export control laws, and linkages to such bilateral issues as US arms sales to Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This analysis of the scope of China's WMD exports requires a major caveat, however.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Tracking China's nuclear, chemical and missile exports based on nonclassified, open- source information is an inherently difficult task.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To offset these informational weaknesses, this paper relies on multiple sourcing combined with extensive conversations with US and Chinese officials from a variety of government agencies in both Washington and Beijing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China and Nuclear Proliferation Chinese nuclear exports have changed dramatically over the course of the last twenty years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The geographic distribution of Chinese nuclear exports has narrowed, the character of nuclear items sold and their relative contribution to nuclear proliferation has positively changed and the frequency of nuclear exports (including technical assistance) has decreased significantly.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As of , US concerns about Chinese actions that contribute to nuclear proliferation are fundamentally different as compared to years ago.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To detail these trends, this section compares China's nuclear exports in the s and s. Chinese Nuclear Exports in the s Beginning in the early s (only a few years after Sino-US normalization), Chinese state owned companies began providing a variety of nuclear assistance to an eclectic mix of countries all over the world.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese nuclear companies used nuclear exports as a means to generate hard currency as China opened up to the outside world and sought to better integrate its economy with Western ones.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Central authorities in Beijing encouraged nuclear exports as a way for China's large military-nuclear complex to diversify into producing civilian goods.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The profits from these activities were then funneled into improving China's dilapidated nuclear infrastructure, both military and civilian.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Given these pressures, Chinese companies began providing nuclear equipment, materials, and technical assistance to such countries as Argentina, Algeria, Brazil, Chile, India, Iran, possibly Iraq, Pakistan, and South Africa.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Initially, Chinese companies sought to create long-term relationships with many of them.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Throughout the s, China signed nuclear cooperation agreements (NCAs) with Argentina, Algeria, Brazil, Iran, Pakistan, and a variety of other countries of lesser proliferation concern in an effort to create sustained export relationships.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Many of these NCAs are currently active, although trade between China and many of these countries has been scaled down in recent years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's nuclear sales covered a variety of nuclear items and technical assistance that directly contributed to the military nuclear activities in several countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the early s, Chinese nuclear exports were not placed under International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards, which facilitated their use in military nuclear activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese firms exported different types of reactor fuel, complete reactors, reactor technologies, technical assistance for indigenous nuclear projects, and nuclear facility training.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the case of Pakistan, China also provided substantial direct assistance in designing and building nuclear weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beginning around , China sold Argentina a wide variety of nuclear materials such as uranium concentrate (yellow cake), uranium hexafloride, -percent low-enriched uranium (LEU), and heavy water.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's exports to Brazil were less extensive but also probably were diverted to Brazil's military nuclear activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China sold some kg of LEU ( - - percent enriched) to Brazil in the early s, none of which was subject to international safeguards.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Of greater proliferation significance were China's nuclear exports to South Africa, which operated a dedicated nuclear weapon program--as opposed to the "military options" programs in Brazil and Argentina.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, China sold South Africa metric tons (MT) of unsafeguarded heavy water for other nuclear projects.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's strong financial motives for exporting nuclear items were especially evident in its willingness to provide nuclear fuel to its strategic competitors.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Between and , China provided India with - MT of unsafeguarded heavy water; this item was probably used in India's CANDU reactors that for many years served as the main plutonium producers for India's nuclear weapons program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese nuclear exports in the s went beyond nuclear fuel.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , China and Algeria signed an agreement for the construction of a small MW heavy-water research reactor.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials originally argued that the reactor deal was exempt from inspection because the contract was signed in , a year before China joined the IAEA.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Only after significant US and international pressure was applied beginning in (when US satellites noticed the reactor's construction) did China and Algeria agreed to open the reactor to IAEA inspection when it was completed.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Ironically, China's nuclear assistance to Iran was of lesser concern in the s. China's nuclear relationship with Iran was just taking shape in the s and did not flourish until the s.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This assistance involved limited amounts of training and nuclear equipment exports; none of it was directly applicable to nuclear weapon development, and all of China's assistance was placed under safeguards.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Reports say that China and Iran signed a secret nuclear cooperation as early as .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The first manifestation of this accord was the training of Iranian technicians in China; by some nuclear engineers from Iran's Isfahan facility had been trained in nuclear reactor design and research in China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , China's initial nuclear exports to Iran were minimal and involved transfers of two or three electromagnetic isotope separators (EMIS or calutrons) and a -kilowatt (kW) subcritical reactor.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese-supplied calutrons were placed under IAEA safeguards and stationed at two facilities in Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese used the subcritical reactor to began training the Iranians in basic nuclear physics, isotope production, and reactor operation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Such training--both in Iran and in China--provided the Iranians with a technical baseline from which greater expertise and presumably nuclear weapon knowledge could eventually be developed.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet all of China's aid was consistent with and, in fact, encouraged under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty (NPT).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During the s, China's nuclear relationship with Pakistan was Beijing's most extensive in terms of the technologies/assistance provided, the contribution to proliferation, and the frequency of transfers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China directly assisted Pakistan's nuclear weapon program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the early part of the decade, China reportedly provided Pakistan with a nuclear weapon design of a crude but highly reliable Hiroshima-sized weapon; reports say China also transferred enough HEU for one or two cores for this weapon; and in China may have allowed Pakistani scientists to observe nuclear tests at Lop Nor.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, Chinese technicians provided equipment and assistance to several of Pakistan's unsafeguarded fuel-cycle facilities that supported the nuclear weapons program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , China concluded a comprehensive nuclear cooperation agreement with Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Under this accord, Chinese companies supplied Pakistan with a variety of nuclear products and services, ranging from uranium enrichment technology to research and power reactors.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Specifically, Chinese scientists may have assisted Pakistan with construction of the PARR- research reactor and operating uranium enrichment centrifuges at the Kahuta facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China also reportedly transferred enough tritium gas to Pakistan for a few nuclear weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's extensive nuclear exports to Pakistan, Argentina, Brazil, and South Africa during the s largely are explained by the weakness of China's formal nonproliferation commitments combined with the relative lack of bureaucratic infrastructure in China to support nuclear nonproliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For years, Chinese officials had rejected the NPT as a biased and inherently discriminatory treaty and viewed nonproliferation as a means for the superpowers to entrench their nuclear superiority by denying other nations equivalent capabilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This view began to change slowly in the s as China re-engaged with the international community.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beginning in , China made two initial nonproliferation commitments, neither of which was verifiable or enforceable.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, China joined the IAEA and pledged to require safeguards on all of its nuclear exports to non-nuclear-weapon states; this promise also included third-party retransfer prohibitions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, China's then Premier Zhao Ziyang provided a verbal commitment in a White House toast that China does not "advocate or encourage nuclear proliferation" and that China "does not engage in nuclear proliferation ourselves, nor do we help other countries develop nuclear weapons."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Both of these commitments probably were motivated by the Chinese desire to conclude negotiations on a bilateral nuclear cooperation agreement so that China could gain access to US reactor technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Neither of these commitments was part of China's export law and probably were not communicated to the Chinese nuclear companies involved in exporting goods.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At that time, China had no functioning export control system, set of export control laws, or technology lists that governed China's nonproliferation commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's arms control and nonproliferation community similarly was underdeveloped.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's nascent community of arms control and nonproliferation experts were based mainly at the UN in New York or at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva and focused on broad arms control issues like nuclear disarmament and nuclear testing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nonproliferation was not an independent discipline in China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's continued nuclear relationship with Pakistan throughout the s provides the best evidence of the limited scope and weaknesses of China's initial nonproliferation pledges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Nuclear Exports in the s By the early s, the character of China's nuclear exports had begun to change.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese companies stopped providing nuclear-specific materials, equipment, and technologies to unsafeguarded facilities in countries with suspected nuclear weapons programs like Argentina, Brazil, India, and South Africa.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The geographic scope of China's nuclear exports declined to cover mainly Iran and Pakistan; the character of China's remaining nuclear exports gradually shifted to dual-use nuclear goods; and the relative contribution of these exports to nuclear proliferation accordingly declined.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These developments were further enhanced by the gradual expansion throughout the s of China's formal nuclear nonproliferation commitments (China signed the NPT in ), its nuclear export control laws, and bureaucratic support within China for nuclear nonproliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's nuclear cooperation with Iran expanded in the early part of the s, but by the end of the decade it had almost entirely stopped.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This contraction was a direct result of US pressure on China to cease all nuclear cooperation with Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beginning in the early s, China signed several reactor deals and contracts for other fuel-cycle-related facilities with Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China sold Iran a small zero-power research reactor and a zirconium tube production facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During this same period, China and Iran concluded a deal for a small MW research reactor.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, by China canceled the deal under US pressure.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials were concerned that the deal would have complicated China's bid to secure renewal of Most-Favored-Nation (MFN) trading status with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Around , China and Iran signed another, larger contract for the export of two megawatts electric (MWe) Qinshan-type reactors and a uranium hexafloride (UF ) production facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials countered that Iran was a member of the NPT, previous inspections had found no evidence of noncompliance with the treaty, and all these facilities were subject to IAEA safeguards.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Sino-US debates about these facilities came to a head in as Beijing and Washington began to discuss implementation of the dormant US-China nuclear cooperation agreement.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In exchange for China's cancellation of these two projects and its agreement to halt all future nuclear cooperation with Iran, the United States would allow the NCA to enter into force.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As part of this deal, China was allowed to continue two nuclear projects: the zero-yield reactor and the zirconium production facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The CIA has verified in several reports to Congress that since China continues to adhere to this pledge to end all nuclear cooperation with Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, as of , almost all of China's nuclear exports to Iran have stopped.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This virtual halt to Sino-Iranian nuclear cooperation stands in stark contrast to the ambitious plans for bilateral nuclear cooperation that Tehran and Beijing reached at the beginning of the decade.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During the s, direct assistance to Pakistan's nuclear weapons program appears to have ended, while the scope of China's other assistance has narrowed significantly.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese firms provided Pakistan with a variety of nuclear goods and technical assistance that indirectly contributed to Pakistan's nuclear weapons program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's assistance to Pakistan on three projects will help to elucidate the scope of the relationship.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, China reportedly provided Pakistan with construction assistance for a - -MW plutonium production reactor at Khushab; this facility is not under IAEA safeguards and, if operational, would provide Pakistan with an unsafeguarded source of plutonium-laden spent fuel.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , for example, a Chinese company exported a special industrial furnace and high-tech diagnostic equipment to the Khushab facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has since promised to halt all assistance to this and other unsafeguarded facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, Chinese firms reportedly were assisting Pakistan with the construction of a partially completed, unsafeguarded reprocessing center located at Chasma; if Pakistan completes this facility, then operating it in conjunction with the Khushab facility would provide Pakistan with an unsafeguarded source of plutonium.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also at the Chasma site, China is building a MWe power reactor for electrical generation purposes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, Chinese work on the reactor could function as a "cover" for assistance to the Chasma reprocessing facility or other projects in Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some sources indicate that Chinese and Pakistani experts already have considered this possibility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Third, in a Chinese firm supplied Pakistan's Kahuta Research Laboratory with , custom-made ring magnets for use in high-speed gas centrifuges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The ring magnet incident was particularly significant because it raised questions about the ability of Chinese officials to control the actions of Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials claimed not to know about the magnet deal, and thus argued they should not be held accountable for it.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The ring-magnet incident was especially important because it both highlighted the emerging problem in the s of the government's difficulty in controlling exports, and catalyzed China to institutionalize many of its nonproliferation commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Following the episode, Chinese officials began to clarify its nuclear nonproliferation commitments and to codify them in domestic law.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , following the incident, China publicly pledged not to "provide assistance to unsafeguarded nuclear facilities."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This promise built on China's NPT obligations by expanding them to cover dual-use nuclear items or any nonnuclear goods to unsafeguarded facilities in Pakistan or other countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's first nuclear export control law was issued and published in and a second one, specifically covering dual-use nuclear goods, was released in June .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since the early s, China has also developed the bureaucratic infrastructure to help implement these commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The China Atomic Energy Agency or CAEA (Zhongguo Guojia Yuanzineng Jigou) in conjunction with MOFTEC and the Foreign Ministry have assumed responsibility for overseeing the nuclear export control process.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Recent organizational changes in China have further bolstered this process.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, the CAEA was separated from the China National Nuclear Corporation which is China's main exporter of nuclear materials, equipment, and technologies; thus the CAEA is no longer subject to the direct pressure of the CNNC when making export control decisions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, the Foreign Ministry within the last two years established a Department of Arms Control and Disarmament Affairs (junkong si) under the directorship of one of China's most experienced arms control experts, Sha Zukang.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This department has an entire division of some experts devoted to Chinese nuclear affairs including nuclear exports and export control issues.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, the Chinese Government continues to have difficulty implementing and enforcing its nonproliferation commitments and nuclear export control laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There are Chinese companies, usually small ones, that either do not know the government's laws or that disregard them in an effort to earn hard currency.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's commercial nuclear ties to Pakistan are deep, which may facilitate continued nuclear-relevant exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The ring-magnet incident in represented the first public instance of the continuing problem of how to promote respect in China for the government's international commitments and domestic laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Until the central government is able to control the activities of these small, "rogue" firms, Chinese nuclear exports will remain an issue of concern for US policymakers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, aside from illicit exports of dual-use equipment and materials, Chinese scientists and technicians may still be providing secret technical assistance to their Pakistani counterparts.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China has adopted controls on exports of nuclear materials, equipment, and technologies, tracking and controlling technical exchanges by personnel is inherently difficult.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Mutual visits by key scientists to weapons-related facilities in both China and Pakistan probably continue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In one instance, China's existing nuclear cooperation with Pakistan on the Chasma power reactor may provide a cover for exchanges related to Pakistan's construction, operation, and maintenance of unsafeguarded facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China and Missile Proliferation

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the last years, China's exports of ballistic and cruise missiles and related technologies have undergone an evolution similar to, but not as dramatic as, the reduction in China's nuclear exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The geographic scope of China's missile exports has narrowed to include Iran, Pakistan, and, to a lesser extent, North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The character of China's missile exports has shifted from sales of complete systems to exports of dual-use missile technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China also has assumed a growing number of missile nonproliferation commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Significant concerns also persist about China's interpretations of its pledges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As of , the principal US concern about China's missile proliferation revolves around the continued export by Chinese firms of dual-use missile technologies and production technologies to organizations in Pakistan, Iran, and North Korea that are involved in missile development.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beginning in the late s and ending in the early s, China actively marketed and sold a variety of complete ballistic and cruise missiles to several countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As early as , China sold hundreds of HY- Silkworm and C- /YJ- cruise missiles to Iran and Iraq; in Iran some of these systems were fitted on land-based batteries for coastal defense, and others were mounted on fast-attack crafts and used to threaten Persian Gulf shipping.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China also provided Iran with production technologies to facilitate indigenous construction of these systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As China's missile cooperation with Iran began to expand rapidly, China exported - DF- (CSS- ) intermediate range ballistic missiles to Saudi Arabia in .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These missiles, drawn from China's stock of aging missiles, possess a range of approximately , km that allowed Saudi Arabia-- for the first time--to target most Middle East capitals.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese exports of complete missiles continued in the late s when Chinese firms began to market and sell the newly developed M- and M- missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The M- and M- were developed specifically for export and were welcome additions to the international missile market in the late s. These missiles, which are Chinese designed and solid fueled, were far more reliable and accurate than the majority of the Scud-derivatives available at that time.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China negotiated with Pakistan, Iran, and Syria for the sale of both M- s and M- s. By late , China and Syria reportedly signed a $ million contract for approximately M- missiles and launchers; the Syrians even provided advance funds for the missiles that the Chinese promptly spent before deliveries began.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China and Iran had also engaged in extensive discussions about exports of M- missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: One report indicated that by January China and Iran agreed on the export of M- missiles and production tooling, suggesting the possible sale of production technologies along with the full missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China also began selling Iran a short-range, battlefield missile with a -km range; it was known as the or CSS- .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: By China had sold some - of these systems to Iran and also had begun providing technologies for the creation of a production line to facilitate Iran's indigenous development of the system.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's discussions with Pakistan focused on the possible supply of the M- missile.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Sino-Pakistani negotiations proceeded quickly, and by China had transferred a training M- missile and launcher.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In response to China's missile marketing, the United States actively sought, and in many cases succeeded, in curbing China's behavior.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Reeling from the shock of China's DF- sale to Saudi Arabia and its perceived impact on Middle East stability, the Bush Administration immediately launched a vigorous effort to halt China's exports of M- and M- missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Finally in late and again in , Chinese officials pledged verbally (and later in writing) that China would adhere to the guidelines and parameters of the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: By assuming this commitment, China was forced to cancel the proposed sale of M- missiles to both Iran and Syria; this was especially difficult in the case of Syria because a contract had been signed and advance funds had been provided to Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The / MTCR commitment is particularly important in evaluating the changes in the scope, content, and frequency of China's missile export activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing's MTCR commitment provided a tangible, upper-bound limit on China's missile export activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since late , China has not sold any complete MTCR-class missiles to any countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing even denied Saudi Arabia's request for replacement versions of the DF- s purchased in .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Rather, China has limited its missile exports to transfers of dual-use missile technologies to Iran, Pakistan, and, to a lesser extent, North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These exports continue today and define the scope and content of China's missile proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Two ambiguities in China's original MTCR pledge have directly influenced the character of China's missile exports in the s. Detailing these areas of confusion will help to explain the scope of China's exports in the last decade.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, US and Chinese officials failed to reach agreement on whether the MTCR covered the M- given its published range of km.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This ambiguity helps to explain the subsequent Sino-US controversy over China's late M- exports to Pakistan; from China's perspective, M- exports to Pakistan were not covered by its MTCR commitment.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A second factor to consider is that in China's original MTCR formulation, Beijing never agreed to accept the MTCR annex, which specifies all of the technologies controlled by this regime.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's reluctance to accept the annex has resulted in the continuation of missile technology exports to Iran, Pakistan, and North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Missile Exports in the s and Beyond Since , Chinese firms have provided limited amounts of dual-use technologies to help Iran build short-range ballistic missiles; some of these technologies also may have been used to improve Iran's medium-range systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese assistance can be divided into two general categories.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On one level, China has provided Iran with production technology for key sub-components for Iran's short-range missiles; these systems are below MTCR parameters and are not prohibited by any international agreement.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China reportedly sold computerized machine tools, specialized steel, gyroscopes, accelerometers, and test equipment that Iran uses to build and test missile airframes and guidance and control systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Based on this type of assistance, Iran has probably developed a self-sufficient production infrastructure for short-range missiles, possibly including the construction of a facility to produce the Chinese missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some reports suggest that China also may have transferred telemetry equipment for use when test launching medium-range missiles banned by the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials continue to defend these deals by citing the dual-use nature of its technology exports to Iran and the lack of agreement between the United States and China on the MTCR technology annex.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, the proliferation significance of China's missile technology exports to Iran must also be evaluated in the context of Iran's overall ballistic missile program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Given the limited scope of China's assistance, its technology exports are not likely to be crucial to the long-term viability of Iran's missile development.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese technologies do not contribute significantly to the development of any of these systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Until China's contributions to Iran's antiship-cruise-missile arsenal were arguably more significant than its ballistic missile assistance in the s. China provided Iran with a full array of antiship cruise missiles and the ability to indigenously produce these systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As mentioned above, in the mid- s China sold Iran hundreds of HY- and C- cruise missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This cooperation expanded in the early part of the s when China began providing Iran with the equipment, materials, and technologies needed to indigenously produce these missile systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As Iran's naval modernization program accelerated in the early s, China and Iran concluded a deal for China's newest and most capable antiship cruise missile known as the C- .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the fall of , China delivered its first shipment of C- s to Iran, and these were quickly followed by the means for Iran to indigenously produce the missile.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This cooperation lasted until Fall when China agreed--under US pressure--to cancel all C- and C- shipments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At that point, China had delivered approximately of the missiles Iran previously ordered.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For months US officials heavily lobbied their Chinese counterparts to cancel these deals by arguing that they would threaten the free flow of oil through the Persian Gulf.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the context of the first Clinton-Jiang summit in October , Chinese Foreign Ministry officials provided Secretary of State Madeline Albright with a verbal pledge that China would cease all C- and C- exports to Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's Defense Minister Chi Haotian reaffirmed this ban in January during meetings with Defense Secretary Cohen; US intelligence documents indicate that during these meetings Chinese military officials also agreed not to provide over-the-horizon targeting for the C- s and C- s Iran already possessed.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Recent questions about China's adherence to its cruise missile export ban have proven unfounded.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In response to press reports that Chinese firms were assisting Iran with air- launched cruise missiles, both the US State Department and China's Foreign Ministry issued statements confirming that the commitment banned exports of only C- s and C- s and not other cruise missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, in the course of years, China's antiship cruise missile assistance had declined dramatically; not only has China stopped selling additional C- s and C- s to Iran but also all production assistance for these missiles has stopped as well.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Similar to China's missile cooperation with Iran, China's assistance to Pakistan's missile programs narrowed significantly in the s. Following the M- deliveries in late , China capped its M- exports to Pakistan and is not known to have supplied Islamabad (or any other country) with MTCR-class missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Rather, Chinese firms have supplied Pakistan with a wide range of equipment, materials, and technologies for its missile programs.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: According to Senate testimony of Gordon Oehler, China has focused on exports of "production technologies and components" for Pakistani missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Much of this assistance has been for China's largest missile project in Pakistan: the construction of a missile production facility at Rawalpindi.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A Pentagon report on global proliferation developments confirmed the existence of this facility and China's central role in the plant's construction.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is reported to have provided Pakistan with the blueprints and much of the equipment to build and possibly to outfit the facility; the plant's construction reportedly began in based on a decade-old contract.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Open sources are unclear whether this facility will be used to build complete missiles or just missile components and sub-systems; this determination will affect China's compliance with the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, until this facility becomes operational, questions will remain about the nature of China's missile assistance to Pakistan and the degree to which China's actions are consistent with its MTCR pledges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As of , China's missile cooperation with Pakistan remains an active issue worthy of significant US and international concern.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's past missile assistance has been extensive (as detailed above), and it is continuing despite the deterioration of the security environment in South Asia.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese firms continue to aid in the construction of the missile facility at Rawalpindi that are likely to produce M- /DF- missiles under the Pakistani designation Hatf- .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, Pakistan's recently tested Shaheen has design characteristics that are similar, but not identical, to China's M- /DF- missile.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China's missile nonproliferation commitments regarding South Asia have recently expanded, Beijing's willingness and ability to implement them remains ambiguous.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Following the June summit meetings in Beijing, the United States and China issued a Joint Statement on South Asia that said "our respective policies are to prevent the export of equipment, materials, or technology that could in any way assist programs in India or Pakistan for nuclear weapons or for ballistic missiles capable of delivering such weapons, and that to this end, we will strengthen our national export control systems."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This statement appears to remove all remaining uncertainty about the commitment of the Chinese Government to halt further missile assistance to Pakistan (including MTCR Category II technologies) and signals China's commitment to begin developing legally based export controls on MTCR-controlled technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, this agreement--which was reached by senior US and Chinese leaders--is opposed by many parts of the Chinese bureaucracy, and Chinese Government officials have done the minimum to implement it.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese firms have deep relationships with their counterparts in Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These Chinese entities often do not share the government's commitment to nonproliferation, and thus Beijing has difficulty controlling their export activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This situation is especially true in the missile realm because China lacks regulations covering these items; thus, the government has no legal basis to monitor or punish firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's Uncontrolled Missile Technology Exports in the s

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The ability and willingness of Chinese firms to sell dual-use missile technologies to potential proliferants is particularly evident in the patterns of exports to countries other than Iran or Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Throughout the s, Chinese firms have concluded a number of deals with potential proliferants.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These deals raise questions about the Chinese Government's ability to control various Chinese companies and, ultimately, to implement China's nonproliferation commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , a Chinese company exported tons of ammonium perchlorate to Syria, possibly for use in making solid rocket fuel; that same year Libya received a shipment of lithium hydride, which has direct application to missile fuel production, and in another Chinese firm also exported ammonium perchlorate to Iraq in direct violation of the UN embargo.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: One of the most recent and most worrisome examples of unapproved assistance involved exports by Chinese firms to North Korea's ballistic missile program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Reports in early indicated that scientists from China's Academy of Launch Technology (CALT) had provided some low-level assistance to engineers in North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese firms also allegedly sold a variety of dual-use technologies to the North including accelerometers, gyroscopes, and specialized machinery used to build missile airframes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, there is little evidence that the Chinese Government approved any of these exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A further confirmation of the links between firms in China and North Korea came in a recent CIA report on global proliferation developments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An unclassified CIA report on proliferation developments in the latter half of indicated that Chinese "entities" had sold specialized steel to the North and had provided some unspecified space technologies to organizations involved in missile development.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Understanding China's Missile Nonproliferation Commitments China's interpretations of it missile nonproliferation commitments lie at the heart of the problem of Beijing's continued sales of missile technologies to Iran and Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As argued above, China's original MTCR pledges suffer from some basic weaknesses.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has never accepted the MTCR annex as the definitive list of items to be controlled under the regime.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has also never accepted the revisions to the MTCR's guidelines and parameters.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, the United States and China have little basis for agreement on which items are banned under the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In stark contrast to China's work in the areas of nuclear and chemical goods, China has not yet issued a series of export control regulations covering MTCR-controlled equipment, materials, and technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Without these regulations, the Chinese Government has no legal authority to monitor, control, or curb the exports of Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Foreign Ministry nonproliferation specialists maintain that, at best, the Foreign Ministry can request that a firm halt certain export activities but their power and influence is limited by the absence of regulations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, Chinese officials generally are reluctant to expand their existing MTCR commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: From its inception, Chinese officials have criticized the MTCR as a discriminatory regime that relies on double standards and that focuses too heavily on the supply side of the issue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In particular, the Chinese are quick to point out that the MTCR does not control exports of strike aircraft, which arguably are better delivery vehicles for WMD than missiles and which the United States sells all over the world.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China agreed during the June Clinton- Jiang summit to "actively study" MTCR membership, Chinese officials have been reluctant to carry out this commitment.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As a result, in the last year, the United States and China have achieved very little movement on China's membership in the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, China's original and subsequent missile nonproliferation commitments are bilateral, political promises made in the context of US-China bargaining.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials probably interpret them from that perspective.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: According to a recent study on Chinese arms exports, "Beijing's pledges may rest more on political understandings about US-China relations rather than apolitical contractual obligations" that uphold international norms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As such, China has begun to link its missile technology exports to changes in US policy, such as reductions in US arms sales to Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese officials and scholars argue that continued US arms sales--particularly missile defense exports to Taiwan--constitute a form of missile proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: They maintain that China will become a member of the MTCR when the United States curbs its military sales to Taiwan.
