Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Foreign Ministry officials argue that only when the United States respects China's security concerns about US weapons exports to Taiwan will China seriously consider US security concerns about China's missile technology cooperation with Iran and Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China and Chemical Weapons Proliferation Unlike Chinese exports in the nuclear and missile areas, China's chemical-weapons (CW)-related exports did not emerge as a serious problem until the early s. China's chemical industry in the s (particularly the private chemical producers) had just begun to grow and expand, and they assumed a wide-scale export orientation only at the beginning of the s.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Yet, the nature of China's CW-related exports has not changed significantly throughout the last decade.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The central problem continues to be illicit sales by Chinese firms operating outside of government control in marketing and selling dual-use items to Iranian and Syrian organizations involved in chemical weapon production.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The linkages between Chinese and Iranian firms have been documented numerous times in official US Government documents and policy statements.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As early as , then CIA Director Robert Gates noted in Congressional testimony that Syrian firms were actively seeking CW production assistance from China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Bruce Reidel added that "Chinese firms have provided some assistance (to Iran), both in terms of infrastructure for building chemical plants and some of the precursors for developing agents."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Defense Department's report on global proliferation developments bluntly affirmed these connections: China is an important supplier of technologies and equipment for Iran's chemical warfare program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Therefore, Chinese supply policies will be key to whether Tehran attains its long-term goal of independent production for these weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US concerns about these activities culminated in May when the United States imposed economic sanctions on three Chinese companies and five Chinese citizens for assisting Iran's chemical weapons program in the early s. This case involved the exports of nerve gas precursors (e.g., thionyl chloride, dimethylamine, and ethylene chlorodydril) and chemical production equipment and technology.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese Government was not implicated in this incident because the exports were attributed to private chemical-producing firms operating without government consent.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In assessing China's CW-related exports to Iran and Syria, one factor that may have declined throughout the last decade has been the frequency of such exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the early part of the s, Chinese exports of CW-related goods largely resulted from the inability of China's export control infrastructure to regulate adequately these types of sales.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China simply lacked the proper regulations, the legal authority, and the bureaucratic structure to control the activities of Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This situation began to change in the mid- s as China assumed a number of international commitments and set up domestic structures to limit CW-related exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beginning with China's signature of the Chemical Weapons Convention in , the Chinese Government has taken numerous steps to erect an extensive chemical export control architecture.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In China issued its first "Regulations on Chemical Export Controls" (Jiankong Huaxuepin Guanli Tiaoli); this law included a "schedule" of controlled chemicals based on the CWC and regulations that provide for strict control on the transfer of items listed in the schedule.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In March , the government issued a supplement to the regulations in preparation for China's CWC ratification.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Ministry of Chemical Industry (MCI) in conjunction with the Foreign Ministry, the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation (MOFTEC), and the Customs Administration jointly issued a circular to further strengthen China's controls on chemical exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Most recently, China expanded the scope of these regulations in June when it added some dual-use chemicals not previously covered in the law.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, powerful bureaucratic interests in the Chinese Government track this issue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's CWC Implementation Office has high-level political backing because its nominal head is Wu Bangguo, a vice premier.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, the Foreign Ministry has a division of some experts within the Department of Arms Control and Disarmament Affairs devoted to tracking China's compliance with the CWC and China's export control laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although the Chinese Government has erected these legal barriers and committed parts of the bureaucracy to monitoring China's chemical exports, Beijing's ability to implement and enforce its laws and commitments remains a continuing challenge.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Despite the promulgation of the laws in and , CW-related exports by Chinese firms to entities in Iran has continued.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In November , China reportedly sold about metric tons of chemicals (including carbon sulfide) used in the production of nerve agents and riot-control and tear gas to an Iranian chemical center.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also in , the US Central Intelligence Agency reported that Iran "obtained considerable CW-related assistance from China in the form of production equipment and technology" and that "Iran obtained the bulk of its CW equipment from China and India."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: More recently, in May the I>Sunday Telegraph reported that a Chinese firm had supplied Iran with tons of phosphorus pentsulphide in consignments of tons each for an estimated $ , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Several factors help to explain the difficulties the Chinese Government faces in curbing the chemical export activities of Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, China's chemical industry is one of its largest and most widely dispersed, and unlike the nuclear and aerospace industries, most chemical exporters are private, nonstate enterprises.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China produces some , chemical products by , chemical producers scattered throughout provinces (not including Taiwan), autonomous regions and municipalities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Gansu Province, which is one of China's most underdeveloped provinces, has chemical production plants.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, the export control culture in China is not strong.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Third, the deal-making activities of certain Chinese individuals, like Chen Qingchang (a.k.a. Q. C. Chen), who operate outside government control, have been instrumental in promoting contracts between Chinese companies and Iranian firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The activities of this individual, in particular, have undermined the Chinese Government's ability to meet its CWC obligations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese Government's apparent inability or unwillingness to control Chen's dealmaking contributes to China's continued chemical exports to Iranian organizations involved in chemical weapons development.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Fourth, US intelligence information on illicit chemical exports that is provided to Chinese officials is often inadequate for investigative purposes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Based on discussions with Chinese Foreign Ministry officials, US intelligence information is normally too vague to help Chinese officials to identify specific firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Because the United States often provides the names of individuals and firms engaging in illegal activity using the pinyin rendering and with little more information, Chinese officials have had significant difficulty identifying the actual firms or persons given, the size of China's chemical industry.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Finally, there is a political dimension to the problem of China's CW-related exports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China rejects membership in the Australia Group (AG) on the grounds that it is not a multilateral treaty like the CWC, that it interferes in the operation of the CWC, and that it unfairly targets countries like Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese companies continue to export dual-use chemicals controlled by the Australia Group (AG), but not the CWC.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As a result, China's political opposition to the AG as a discriminatory and redundant regime has been the source of several bilateral disputes with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These five problems suggest that, although the frequency of China's CW-related exports may be declining, the Chinese Government continues to face the difficult task of implementing and enforcing the laws its has adopted.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Until the Chinese Government is able to establish an effective system for monitoring and controlling the export behavior of its chemical firms, then CW-related exports probably will continue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Conclusions and Implications for US Policy China's WMD proliferation activities have undergone a significant transition in the last twenty years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The geographic scope: the types of technologies; and the frequency of Beijing's nuclear, chemical, and missile exports have all declined over the last two decades.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the s, Chinese firms were directly assisting military nuclear activities in a variety of countries all over the world, Chinese entities were marketing and selling complete ballistic and cruise missiles to several nations in the Middle East and South Asia, and in some cases these nuclear and missile exports involved transfers of critical technologies for indigenous production.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Today, the nature of China's WMD-related exports has declined significantly as compared to the activity in the s. Exports are limited to three countries (Iran, Pakistan, and, to a lesser degree, North Korea), these deals involve mostly dual-use nuclear, chemical, and missile technologies that at best indirectly assist WMD development, and the frequency of such exports appears to have slowed to a dribble.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An additional element of the current situation is that some of these exports, particularly from the chemical industry, are the result of Chinese firms operating beyond government controls, not deliberate government policy decisions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's current WMD proliferation activities are fundamentally different from those of a decade ago.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: None of this is meant to suggest that China's current WMD-related exports are not a serious problem for US policymakers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Given these threats to US security, the challenge for US policymakers is to develop policies that address the current scope of the China proliferation activities, not the past problem.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The current US burden is no longer to convince China to fully embrace the nonproliferation regime with all its treaties, agreements, control lists, and legal obligations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has largely done this on a broad scale in the areas of nuclear exports, chemical exports, and, to a lesser extent, ballistic missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As this paper has documented, in multiple instances in the s and s US intervention was instrumental in bringing about the cancellation or limitation of Chinese nuclear, chemical, and missile assistance to Algeria, Iran, Pakistan, and Syria.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some seize on any Chinese military export as a nonproliferation violation without considering the type of transfer or the precise nature of China's commitments and bilateral differences about those pledges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Few acknowledge the narrowing of China's WMD proliferation activities, the expansion of its formal commitments, and the growth in government resources used to implement these pledges.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During Congressional debates about China in , three prominent Congressmen called China "the Wal-Mart of international nuclear commerce," and the Cox Committee Report characterized China as "one of the leading proliferators of complete ballistic missiles systems" based on its exports of missiles in the late s and early s. China's past proliferation transgressions are being used to evaluate Beijing's current and future behavior without regard for the US successes in limiting Beijing's WMD proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The current policy challenges presented by China's remaining WMD proliferation activities are subtler.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On one level, the United States must encourage the Chinese Government to fully comply with and implement its nonproliferation commitments by cracking down on Chinese entities engaged in exports that violate the government's obligations and domestic Chinese law.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On a second level, US policymakers must seek to curb China's authorized assistance (regardless of how limited) to Iran and Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese and US policymakers share few foreign policy interests and national security concerns in their respective relationships with Iran and Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Developing common security perceptions of global proliferation developments may help both sides set appropriate expectations and address the domestic challenges Beijing faces in controlling exports of WMD-related technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This approach is particularly important in light of Beijing's linkage of proliferation issues, such as missile exports to Iran, to Sino-US bilateral relations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These two challenges, combined with the narrowing of China's proliferation activities, raise questions about whether past policies can work effectively on this narrower range of problems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There is little international consensus about many dual-use goods, legal determinations are often politically controversial, and the practical impact of sanctions on Chinese behavior is potentially negative.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Furthermore, intensifying diplomatic pressure on China carries its own inherent risks.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US policymakers must be careful not to damage China's current nonproliferation commitments in pursuing an absolute end to all of Beijing's WMD proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Such an outcome is possible given the current climate in which Beijing closely links its positions on arms control and nonproliferation to the overall state of US-China relations, US arms sales to Taiwan, and, recently, US missile defense proposals.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An understanding of these linkages is dangerously absent from US debates on China's proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Stopping China's unauthorized WMD-related exports will require greater cooperation than has existed to date.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Both nations must take steps to improve China's capacity to recognize and address this issue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, the United States and China could improve the quality of intelligence sharing on both sides and could expand the scope of bilateral dialogues on export control training.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some initial steps could involve expanding the depth of bilateral dialogues to isolate the key policy differences between Beijing and Washington.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nongovernment exchanges open up channels of communication on sensitive issues and, in a broad sense, promote the growth of epistemic communities in China involved in arms control and nonproliferation research.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The expansion of these communities is particularly important in improving China's institutional capacity to address the increasingly complex global arms control and nonproliferation agenda.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As US policymakers consider the range of options to address China's WMD proliferation activities, past successes and recent progress in narrowing the scope of this problem should not be forgotten.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Future progress will require, on the one hand, good bilateral relations to develop deeper cooperation and, on the other, a willingness in both countries to manage the more complex proliferation questions resulting from fundamental differences between Washington and Beijing about foreign policy and nonproliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The proximate US goal should be to remain vigilant about monitoring China's behavior and to expand cooperation in order to address the new nonproliferation challenges described above while preserving existing cooperation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Appendix I China's Nuclear Technology Exports in the s and s Appendix II China's Missile Technology Exports in the s and Appendix III Summary of China's Esport Control Regulations and Decrees Appendix IV Chinese Participation in International Export Control Regimes Chinese Proliferation of Missiles and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Issues for US Policy

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: We are here to examine the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and missiles by the People's Republic of China (PRC) because of the threat it continues to pose to US national security interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This paper does not review in detail the PRC's proliferation activities over the years, which have included transfers to Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Iran, and North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The discussion here addresses the salient issues for US policy to counter threats to US national security interests posed by the PRC's proliferation of WMD and missiles that could deliver them.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, a policy that maximizes gains for US interests would be grounded in a correct assessment of the nature of this PRC threat.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This paper contends that, despite the efforts of successive administrations (since at least the Reagan administration), an important gap remains between US and PRC perceptions about weapon proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, the PRC sees WMD nonproliferation less as its national interest and more as useful leverage in its top foreign policy priority--relations with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As leverage in a realpolitik and hostile world, weapon proliferation is an issue that the PRC employs in affirmative and negative dimensions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At the same time, US leverage in securing PRC commitments to WMD nonproliferation has dissipated, even as the divide widens in Washington over the strategy for dealing with Beijing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Competing US and PRC National Interests Some in the administration (particularly the State Department) and others argue that the PRC has increasingly recognized the value of WMD and missile nonproliferation for its national interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: They point to the steps that the PRC has taken to support the international nonproliferation regimes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since , Beijing--facing significant US, Japanese, and other pressures--has taken several steps to advance its nonproliferation commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China unilaterally promised to abide by the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) in February and reaffirmed that commitment in its October , statement.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, the PRC is not considered a "member" or "partner" of the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China acceded to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty (NPT) on March , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China signed the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) in January .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In November , China issued its first public defense white paper, which focused on arms control and disarmament.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On May , , the Chinese issued a statement promising to make only safeguarded nuclear transfers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China, on July , , began a moratorium on nuclear testing and signed the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) in September .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On April , , China deposited its instrument of ratification of the CWC.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On October , , China joined the Zangger Committee.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Chinese issued new export control regulations on dual-use nuclear items on June , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nevertheless, others in and outside the administration, especially in Congress, contend that the PRC's troubling transfers continue to threaten US national security interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Director of Central Intelligence (DCI), in June , submitted a required report to Congress stating that, during July-December , China was "the most significant supplier" of WMD-related goods and technology to foreign countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The DCI's latest report (issued in July ) on the last half of named China (along with Russia and North Korea) as a "key supplier" of such technology, having transferred supplies to Pakistan, Iran, and North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: India conducted nuclear tests on May and , , citing China's nuclear ties to Pakistan, and Pakistan followed with nuclear tests on May and , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC, Pakistan's military and nuclear supplier, failed to avert the tests and did not cut off nuclear aid or impose other sanctions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The DCI reported in February that China provided "extensive support" in the past to Pakistan's WMD program, and "some assistance continues."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In a public speech on September , , Robert Walpole, the National Intelligence Officer for Strategic and Nuclear Programs, assured us that China or Russia currently are unlikely to sell an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) or a space launch vehicle to convert to an ICBM, but warned that this situation may change over the long term.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On February , , DCI George Tenet testified to the Senate Armed Services Committee that "both the Chinese Government and Chinese firms have longstanding and deep relationships with proliferant countries, and we are not convinced that China's companies fully share the commitments undertaken by senior Chinese leaders."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In early , press reports revealed that the Clinton administration has suspected since that China acquired in the s the design for the most advanced miniature US nuclear warhead (W ) from Los Alamos National Laboratory.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If China acquired the W design, that would help explain the series of Chinese nuclear tests leading up to its moratorium on nuclear testing and willingness to sign the CTBT in .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On April , , the DCI took the unusual step of publicly confirming that the Intelligence Community concluded that "China obtained by espionage classified US nuclear weapons information that probably accelerated its program to develop future nuclear weapons."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The damage assessment ominously cautioned that the proliferation threat has increased, saying that the PRC could now pass US nuclear weapon secrets to other countries, although whether China has done so is unknown.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The assessment warned that, since the Chinese have more modern US nuclear weapon information, they "might be less concerned about sharing their older technology."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The House Select Committee on US National Security/Commercial Concerns with the People's Republic of China (PRC), also known as the Cox Committee, released its unclassified report on May , , replete with concerns about technology transfers to China, including nuclear weapon information.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There are other indications of division with the US Government over policy toward China and assessments of the problem of PRC weapons proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The White House agreed to hold twin summits with the PRC in October and June , advancing the notion of Presidents Clinton and Jiang Zemin of building a "constructive strategic partnership," and the Administration promised to issue certifications to implement the Nuclear Cooperation Agreement as the centerpiece of the summit.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The November East Asia Strategy Report of Secretary of Defense William Cohen declined to include that characterization of US-PRC relations and criticized continuing Chinese missile and chemical proliferation activities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On January , --just two weeks after Presidential certifications were issued on China's nonproliferation credentials--DCI George Tenet testified that "China's relations with some proliferant countries are long-standing and deep" and that "the jury is still out on whether the recent changes are broad enough in scope and whether they will hold over the longer term."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some have questioned whether China has assisted North Korea's missile program, which included the surprising test-firing of a three-stage, medium-range Taepo Dong ballistic missile on August , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: One could argue that Chinese national interest is not to promote advances in North Korea's missile program, since that increased threat has galvanized US and Japanese support for development of theater ballistic missile (TMD) systems, which China opposes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nonetheless, the National Security Agency (NSA) is said to have reported on March , , that China sold specialty steel for use in North Korea's missile program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In June , US intelligence found that Chinese entities transferred accelerometers, gyroscopes, and precision grinding machinery to North Korea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The DCI confirmed publicly for the first time in July that "North Korea obtained raw materials for its ballistic missile programs, especially from firms in China" in the second half of .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: After the mistaken bombing of the PRC Embassy in Belgrade in May , one of Beijing's first reactions was to suspend discussions on international security and arms control with Washington, even as Acting Under Secretary of State John Holum was preparing to visit China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On April , , after a meeting with visiting Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, President Clinton acknowledged that they discussed issues of disagreement, including "limiting the spread of weapons of mass destruction," and Premier Zhu reportedly promised that China will soon ratify the CTBT.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, the PRC still has not ratified the CTBT, and President Jiang Zemin's reported assurances in Paris in October did not include the timetable of ratification "soon."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: After the US Senate's rejection of the CTBT, the PRC is even less likely to ratify the treaty.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In short, the PRC has both issued certain nonproliferation assurances as well as continued to spread dangerous technology and condone even nuclear weapon proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing's deficient commitment to weapons nonproliferation has given rise to competing assessments and increasingly public divisions within the US Government.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The United States and the PRC have competing visions of the world order, and to reserve premature assumptions that Beijing has adopted weapon nonproliferation as one of its national interests or that, over time, Beijing will learn nonproliferation principles and practices would be prudent.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC will continue to calculate the gains of cooperation (concession) or noncooperation (retribution) on weapon nonproliferation as a function of the state of relations with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Weapon proliferation accords Beijing with important leverage against Washington that it will not likely surrender.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US Policy Options Chinese proliferation as a policy issue concerns the priority of this issue relative to other US national interests (i.e., other security issues, human rights, and trade), the Administration's response, including the enforcement of nonproliferation laws, and possible legislation to reduce the danger.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Congress has been concerned about the appropriate US response to Chinese transfers that may have violated international agreements and/or contradicted US laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Allowed by export licenses and presidential waivers of post- Tiananmen crackdown sanctions (in PL - ), the United States, since , has exported satellites to be launched by China Great Wall Industry Corp. (the same company sanctioned for missile proliferation).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The National Security Council, in a Secret memo on bilateral talks leading up to the summit in June (dated March , and printed in the Washington Times), proposed to expand space cooperation with Beijing, increase the number of satellites that China can launch, issue a blanket presidential waiver of sanctions, and support China's membership in the MTCR--in return for effective Chinese export controls on missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, Congress investigated in whether exports of satellites to China has indirectly assisted China's ballistic missile and space programs, and satellite exports have become a controversial issue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As agreed during the US-China summit in October , President Clinton, on January , , signed certifications (as required by PL - ) about China's nuclear nonproliferation policy and practices to implement the Nuclear Cooperation Agreement.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: According to President Clinton, the agreement serves US national security, and environmental and economic interests, and "the United States and China share a strong interest in stopping the spread of weapons of mass destruction and other sophisticated weaponry in unstable regions and rogue states-- notably, Iran."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US firms may apply for Export-Import Bank financing and licenses from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and DOE to export nuclear technology to China, and foreign firms may apply to re-export US technology.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, at the summit in Beijing in June , the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Chinese State Planning Commission signed an agreement on peaceful nuclear cooperation, including bringing Chinese engineers and scientists to US national laboratories, universities, nuclear reactor facilities, and other institutions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Sec. of the National Defense Authorization Act for FY makes permanent a ban on activities with China in cooperative stockpile stewardship.

Sentence: The Cox Committee and the Intelligence Community have expressed strong concerns about PRC acquisition of US nuclear weapon secrets.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some in Congress, the nonproliferation community, and elsewhere have been skeptical that Chinese policies changed sufficiently to warrant the certifications and that they are in US interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, past Chinese assurances have proven unreliable, and concerns have persisted about China's nuclear, missile, and chemical-weapon-related transfers (especially to Pakistan and Iran).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China did not promise to stop nuclear cooperation with Pakistan and did not make a public pledge to stop nuclear assistance for Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, China has not shown a satisfactory track record on nuclear export controls nor adopted all international nonproliferation standards (by joining the Nuclear Suppliers Group).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, there were concerns that any potential sanctions would hurt US businesses involved with the China National Nuclear Corporation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Third, some were concerned that China could retransfer US technology to countries seeking nuclear weapons technology and indirectly use the technology in China's nuclear weapons program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Last, some are skeptical of any huge potential for US exports, saying that China aims to expand foreign competitors for its business and adopt US technology in its own designs to reduce imports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Indeed, Nucleonics Week reported on March , , that US firms no longer expected China to order new foreign reactors soon.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Supporters in the administration, particularly the Departments of State and Energy, US nuclear industry, and others have argued that nuclear technology offers a source of leverage to advance US goals and the agreements with China so far should be "pocketed."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China indicated ambitious plans to expand its nuclear power generation and needed Western technology.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US nuclear cooperation presented a positive incentive for the Chinese nuclear industry to stop sales that contribute to nuclear proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Referring to China's May , commitment, President Clinton stated in a speech on China on October , , that "China has lived up to its pledge not to assist unsafeguarded nuclear facilities in third countries."

Sentence: Some added that conditions for US- China nuclear cooperation should not be changed in the middle of negotiations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, supporters argued that French, Canadian, and Russian companies were already selling nuclear technology to China.

Sentence: DOE said that China will account for one-third of the increase in the world's nuclear power in the next years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China responded by implementing a set of regulations (not a law) on nuclear export controls signed by Premier Li Peng on September , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There were concerns, however, that the China Atomic Energy Authority (CAEA)--in charge of nuclear export controls, was headed by the president of the China National Nuclear Corporation, with competing interests in nuclear exports.

Sentence: Also, whether China's nuclear weapons labs (and their contacts with Pakistan) were covered was unclear.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Policy debates concerning Chinese technology transfers have often centered on the question of whether to impose unilateral sanctions as required by various US laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although certain Chinese transfers may not violate any international treaties, US sanctions may be required under US laws.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Underlying the question of whether sanctions should be used are disagreements about the most effective approach for curbing dangerous Chinese sales and promoting US interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: They refer to reports that China continues to transfer dangerous technology in defiance of the nonproliferation regimes and note the lack of Chinese participation in some significant international groups, such as the Nuclear Suppliers Group.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This school of thought believes that Chinese transfers may pose a threat in the long term and that a necessary military response to resulting threats against Americans or our allies would be terribly costly--as in the Persian Gulf War.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some who argue for a tough approach say that China has made commitments to nonproliferation after facing US pressures and is more likely to restrain its proliferation activities if there are concrete and costly consequences tailored to penalize specific Chinese violators.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: They argue that the United States needs to stay "commercially engaged" in China to influence Chinese policies, especially over the longer term.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US policy since the s has been one of "engagement," to bring China into the world community with subsequent acceptance of the international "rules of conduct."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Those arguing against the use of sanctions often say that sanctions are too broad or are not warranted, and refer to the progress China has made since in joining nonproliferation regimes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: They add that cultivating relationships with China's military leaders is important, because they have important influence over arms sales.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It avoided imposing sanctions on the PRC for nuclear weapon proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In early , some in Congress called for sanctions after reports said that China sold unsafeguarded ring magnets to Pakistan in - , apparently in violation of the NPT and US laws, including the Arms Export Control Act and Export-Import Bank Act (as amended by the Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act of ).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On February , , the Washington Times first disclosed intelligence reports that the China National Nuclear Corporation, a state-owned corporation, transferred to the A.Q. Khan Research Laboratory in Kahuta, Pakistan, , ring magnets, which can be used in gas centrifuges to enrich uranium.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On May , , the State Department announced its decision to not impose sanctions against China and Pakistan, citing a new agreement with China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Administration officials said China promised to provide future assistance only to safeguarded nuclear facilities, reaffirmed its commitment to nuclear nonproliferation, and agreed to consultations on export control and proliferation issues.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The administration also said that Chinese leaders insisted they were not aware of the magnet transfer and that there is no evidence that the Chinese Government had willfully aided or abetted Pakistan's nuclear weapons program through the magnet transfer.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, the State Department announced that sanctions were not warranted, and Export-Import Bank considerations of loans for US exporters to China were returned to normal.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On May , , China's foreign ministry issued a statement that "China will not provide assistance to unsafeguarded nuclear facilities."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In any case, China since has declared a policy of nuclear nonproliferation and requirement for recipients of its transfers to accept IAEA safeguards.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China formalized this policy by acceding to the NPT in .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Moreover, since the Clinton administration began, it has been faced with intelligence reports that the PRC transferred complete M- short-range ballistic missiles to Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On August , , however, the administration imposed lesser category II sanctions on the PRC for transferring M- equipment (not whole missiles) to Pakistan and agreed in October to waive those sanctions, after Beijing promised not to export ground-to-ground missiles "inherently capable" of delivering a -kg warhead km.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The administration has not imposed missile proliferation sanctions on the PRC since then.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nonetheless, Gordon Oehler, soon after stepping down as head of the CIA's Nonproliferation Center, testified on June , , to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that in November , "the Chinese delivered M- s to Pakistan."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: On September , , the CIA confirmed for the first time in a public report that "Pakistan has M- SRBMs from China" and they may have a nuclear role.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In any case, China has not faced sanctions for its reported transfers of complete M- missiles to Pakistan, despite the State Department's study of the issue for the last seven years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Confirming long-suspected Chinese transfers contributing to chemical weapon proliferation, the Administration, on May , , imposed sanctions on two Chinese companies, five Chinese citizens, and a Hong Kong company for chemical-weapons- related transfers to Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Sanctions were not imposed on the Chinese or Hong Kong governments, because the State Department said that it had no evidence that those governments were involved in the transfers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Despite news and intelligence reports that the PRC has proliferated chemical weapons since February , new sanctions have not been imposed.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In July , the DCI reported that, in , Iran acquired CW-related material "primarily" from Chinese firms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The DCI reported in July that Chinese entities continued to be "significant suppliers" of chemical-weapons-related items to Iran in the second half of .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the s, Congress has annually debated whether to link conditions to normal trade relations (NTR) (formerly most-favored-nation status) for China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Because China has an increasing and significant trade surplus with the United States and the Chinese economy depends on the US market, some believe that trade is a powerful policy tool to advance vital US goals.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Congress has not passed legislation to deny normal trade status for China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It is also doubtful that conditions would be attached to the PRC's enjoying permanent NTR status or entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To avoid broad sanctions or steps that may affect US companies, some have proposed controls on imports of products produced by Chinese military or defense-industrial companies suspected of contributing to WMD proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Export controls are an important policy tool, because US technology provides one source of leverage over Beijing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, the Reagan administration, in , froze export control liberalization because China sold Silkworm anti-ship missiles to Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some in Congress are concerned about US technology reaching hostile states with WMD programs through China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: US military sales to China have not been allowed since sanctions were imposed after the Tiananmen crackdown, but there is increasing demand to export dual-use technology that could enhance China's military capabilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Such efforts have two prongs: encouraging Chinese support for strengthening the regimes to enforce compliance and filling gaps in China's participation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some say that including China would capitalize on its desire to be treated as a "great power" and to be perceived as a responsible world leader.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, China might be more cooperative if it helped to draw up the "rules."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Others, however, argue that China's participation would obstruct efforts for tighter export controls, derail arms control efforts, link them to the Taiwan issue (e.g., the Mideast arms control talks), or weaken provisions (e.g., the CTBT).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The United States and others might encourage China to join the MTCR (as a member after it establishes a record of compliance and effective export controls), Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG), Australia Group (on chemical and biological weapons), and Wassenaar Arrangement (military and dual-use export controls).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Indeed, the National Security Council in a Secret memo, dated March , (printed in the March , Washington Times), proposed in a "China missile deal" to expand space cooperation with Beijing, increase the number of satellites that China can launch, issue a blanket presidential waiver of post-Tiananmen sanctions on satellite launches, and support China's membership in the MTCR--in return for effective Chinese missile export controls.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, membership in the MTCR would exempt China from certain sanctions (unless the laws on missile nonproliferation are amended), provide it with intelligence, give it a potentially obstructionist role in decisionmaking, and relax missile-related export controls to China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At the summit in Beijing in June , China did not agree to join the MTCR but said it is "actively studying" whether to join.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In Washington on January , , China's chief arms control official, Ambassador Sha Zukang, signaled opposition to the MTCR by proposing that it be replaced with a multilateral Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Indeed, in , Congress passed a law placing conditions on the PRC's membership in the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China joined the Zangger Committee (on nuclear trade) in October .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: But China is the only major nuclear supplier to shun the -nation NSG, which requires "full-scope safeguards"(IAEA inspections of all other declared nuclear materials and facilities in addition to the facility importing supplies to prevent diversions to weapon programs).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Such a requirement would have important implications for the PRC's continuing nuclear cooperation with Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Regional Security Talks Chinese support may be sought for regional arms control groups, such as multilateral talks for South Asia.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: After Bush's decision, announced on September , , to sell Taiwan F- fighters, China suspended its participation in the talks.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Foreign and Defense Policies Comprehensive Engagement The administration resumed high-level exchanges and pursues "comprehensive engagement" with China to advance US security goals, including nonproliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: President Clinton granted Jiang Zemin two summits in eight months: in Washington, on October , , and in Beijing, on June , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The summit in Beijing produced an agreement on nontargeting nuclear weapons, and Joint Statements on South Asia and on biological weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Also, China refused to join the MTCR but said it is "actively studying" whether to join.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Critics say that little was achieved and China should not be in the MTCR.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Clinton administration participated in the first "track " arms control dialogue with China in Beijing on September - , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is opposed strongly to US deployment of missile defense systems or cooperation with Japan or Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is concerned that missile defense programs would bring an arms race, weaken its deterrence capabilities, and forge closer US-Taiwan military cooperation akin to an alliance.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As required by the FY National Defense Authorization Act, the Defense Secretary submitted a report in May on TMD systems that could be transferred to Japan, South Korea, and/or Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Taiwan China has increasingly tried to link missile nonproliferation to the Taiwan issue, particularly US arms sales to Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nevertheless, during President Clinton's visit to China in June , the administration considered, then disagreed on, a Chinese request for a US pledge to deny TMD technology with Taiwan, if China promised to stop missile proliferation with Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: International Lending and Japan Congress may seek to link US support for loans made by international financial institutions to China's nonproliferation record.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, US influence is limited, and the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank have resumed and increased substantial lending to China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Moreover, as part of the sanctions imposed after the Tiananmen crackdown, the United States has supported only international loans for basic human needs in China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Coordination with Japan is important, since it provides the most significant bilateral aid to China and was the only country to use aid to pressure China to stop nuclear testing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In May , Tokyo suspended the small, grant portion of its aid program in China to protest Chinese nuclear testing, and Tokyo restored the aid (worth about $ million) only after Beijing began a moratorium on nuclear testing.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In conclusion, a common strategy supported throughout and executed at the highest levels of the US Government is needed to counter the threat of weapon proliferation posed by the PRC and other countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, an example of mixed signals is the Pentagon's November East Asia Strategy Report, which criticized continuing Chinese missile and chemical proliferation activities but nonetheless listed weapon nonproliferation as eighth on a list of nine elements of the strategy.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Instead, the Department of Defense, speaking the language of national security, could be a useful voice on nonproliferation as it pursues military relations with the People's Liberation Army (PLA).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Indeed, during his visit to Beijing in January , Defense Secretary Cohen secured some assurances from the PRC President on stopping transfers of anti-ship cruise missiles to Iran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Many are concerned that the administration may negotiate away important benefits for Beijing, with few lasting gains.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It cited Chinese proliferation activities as contributing to that threat and called for Presidential leadership, a new National Director for Combating Proliferation, better policy implementation, and creation of a new budget category.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, concerted US leadership in the world is needed, especially since multilateral efforts would be more effective against a PRC wary of international isolation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Confusing messages were sent when the State Department sought a way out of sanctions for transferring ring magnets, when President Clinton certified the PRC's nonproliferation practices so an export agreement could be implemented and a summit could claim a centerpiece, and similarly when the United States signed the CTBT, but the Senate was able to reject the treaty in October .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As US-PRC relations will continue to be rocky, especially over Taiwan and missile defense, the outlook for PRC cooperation in weapon nonproliferation will be unfavorable for US national interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: While effective bilateral relations are important for securing PRC cooperation in weapon nonproliferation, US national interests ought not be negotiated away for short-term gains.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese Views of Weapons of Mass Destruction Michael D. Swaine

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This chapter examines Chinese views regarding the possession, use, and transfer of weapons of mass destruction (WMD), including nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons and their principal means of delivery.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These views are derived from an examination of Chinese statements and practices concerning WMD as well as assessments provided by knowledgeable experts on China and WMD issues.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This chapter does not present a detailed analysis of China's WMD force structure, deployments, or modernization program.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Such features are discussed only insofar as they shed light on Chinese viewpoints and beliefs toward WMD.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The chapter begins with a summary of four major factors influencing Chinese attitudes toward WMD.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: It then presents an assessment of China's basic view since regarding the use, possession, and transfer of WMD.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This section is followed by a discussion of several modifications in China's basic viewpoint as a result of several major developments occurring largely since the seventies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The chapter concludes with some speculations on the possible future evolution of Chinese views toward WMD possession, use, and transfer.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Major Factors Influencing China's Attitude Toward WMD China's basic viewpoint toward weapons of mass destruction has been influenced by four basic factors: ( ) geostrategic realities; ( ) historical experience; ( ) leadership perceptions and beliefs; and ( ) technological, organizational, and economic capabilities and limitations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's approach to WMD is greatly conditioned by the basic geostrategic environment confronting the Chinese state.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The most significant and enduring features of this environment are: (a) the existence of a very long and in many places geographically porous border; (b) the presence along or near this border of many nation states, some possessing relatively sophisticated military forces; and (c) in recent decades, the nearby presence of two large nuclear weapons powers (Russia and the United States) and a proto-nuclear power (India), all of which have either threatened or fought with China since .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These basic features have required the construction by China of a military force sufficient to deter large-scale conventional and WMD threats and attacks, to defend Chinese territory against an actual invasion should deterrence fail, and generally to sustain Chinese political and military influence along the periphery.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Moreover, as discussed in greater detail below, shifts in the specific disposition and type of geostrategic threats posed to China since by major WMD-armed powers (and in particular Russia and the United States) have exerted an important influence on the possession and potential use by China of weapons of mass destruction, whereas alterations in the larger international environment relating to WMD issues (e.g., the emergence of a robust set of WMD-oriented arms control regimes) have affected China's approach to WMD possession and transfer in particular.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's historical experience in the modern era (i.e., since the mid- th century) has served to enhance the sense of insecurity and resulting vulnerability created by China's geostrategic environment as well as China's desire for great power status.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Specifically, China has been the object of armed intervention, subjugation, and humiliation by foreign industrial powers at various times during the past nearly one hundred and fifty years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, China's longstanding position as the preeminent power in East Asia has served to intensify Chinese sensitivity to foreign threats and slights while strengthening the desire for renewed international respect and equal treatment for China as a major power in the international community.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese leadership perceptions and beliefs have exerted a significant influence over China's rhetorical stance toward WMD possession, use, and transfer, as well as more substantive elements of WMD doctrine and force structure.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese leaders believe that the threat of WMD use has been employed by larger, more developed powers such as the former Soviet Union and the United States to intimidate and blackmail weaker, smaller powers and generally to maintain the dominant influence of such larger powers within the international system.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, weapons of mass destruction are viewed by Chinese leaders as a major stimulus to great power rivalry and global instability.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Of even greater importance, the Chinese leadership believes that China has been a primary target of WMD threats and deployments by the superpowers since the fifties and sixties.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In particular, the United States leveled nuclear threats against China and, in the view of some Chinese, employed chemical and biological weapons against Chinese troops during the Korean war, while the Soviets indirectly threatened the use of nuclear weapons against China in the sixties.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, both countries have targeted China with strategic nuclear weapons and deployed tactical nuclear (and possibly, in the case of the former Soviet Union, chemical and biological) weapons along China's periphery.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Finally, China was subjected to biological weapons use by Japan during WWII and large quantities of chemical weapons abandoned by Japanese troops remain in China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Arguably the greatest impact on China's viewpoint toward WMD possession has been exerted by basic technological, organizational, and economic factors.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
