Sentence: There are persistent rumors of PLA procurement or joint production arrangement on the Kh- P, which Chinese engineers note was specifically developed to counter the US AWACS, PATRIOT MPQ- radar, and AEGIS SPY- D phased-array radar.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's defense industrial complex, specifically the Third Academy with support from the Harbin Institute of Technology, is aggressively pursuing deployment of a long-range antiradiation missile.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese research indicates China's first-generation antiradiation missile will be air launched.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's indigenous remote sensing program and future commercial sources will provide even more precise data.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Because of the requirement for large databases and computer operations, the mission- planning process likely would be centralized in Beijing and then transmitted to the theater operations command center.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There is some indication China is examining integrating combined GPS/GLONASS receivers on board their missiles as well.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For terminal planning, the most advanced PLA system under development is digital scene matching area correlation (DSMAC) system.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A PLA targeteer probably would obtain a photograph of the targeted area and would generate DSMAC scenes for programming into the cruise missile's flight computer.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA GSD intelligence analysts would identify targets of interest and then either pull the image from the library or task China's remote-sensing community to procure the image.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA GSD targeteers would then select aimpoints to exploit the most vulnerable aspect of a command and control facility or airfield.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA's deep-attack strategy, however, does not necessarily require a rapid mission-planning process because most targets on Taiwan would be strategic and static in nature.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An air-launched Silkworm LACM is likely to use PLA Air Force subordinated B- s. If the YJ- is fielded as an LACM, tactical fighter-bombers such as the FB- would serve as the primary platform.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: There are indications the PLA Navy may be seeking to expand its mission to include conventional missile strikes against land-based targets from the sea.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's Third Academy intends to upgrade its cruise missile production capacity, extend the range and speed of their cruise missiles, diversifying its choices of terminal guidance systems, and lower their radar-cross-section.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: CASC's world-class simulation facility in western Beijing also aids cruise missile development by theoretically reducing testing requirements by to percent and shortening overall development time by to percent.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Acquisition of advanced Western systems also could reduce production time--Chinese engineers have reportedly had access to an intact Tomahawk that fell into Afghanistan territory in August .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In one of China's most significant aerospace programs, the PLA General Armament Department (GAD) and the Third Academy are designing a supersonic combustion ramjet engine (scramjet, or chaoran chongya fadongji) that can propel a missile at hypersonic speeds of between Mach and .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The anticipated range of China's first generation of land-attack cruise missiles would be limited to about to km.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: With foreign assistance, China's defense industrial complex also is striving to reduce the radar-cross-section of their cruise missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese aerospace engineers believe synthetic- aperture radar, millimeter-wave radar, and infrared imaging, and laser radar guidance could result in an accuracy of one to three meters.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Conventional Second Artillery The PLA entity most responsible for deep-strike missions against vital strategic and operational targets is the Second Artillery (dierpaobing).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Following the conclusion of the Gulf war, however, Chinese planners diversified the Second Artillery's mission to include conventional strikes against high-value strategic targets.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Second Artillery's adoption of a conventional strike role marks one of the most significant developments in PLA modernization.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Unit, headquartered in the mountain resort town of Huangshan, Jiangxi Province, is the Second Artillery's most important base for conventional long-range precision strikes against Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The corps command post would consist largely of command authorities from Beijing and Huangshan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing is examining a wide range of technologies to reduce vulnerabilities of its communications to interception or jamming.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing has issued directives to strictly implement communications security (COMSEC) measures.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Engineers are studying the application of spread spectrum and frequency hopping technology for Beijing's satellite tracking and control network, as well as more secure satellite communications methodologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is also investing in more complex encryption (mimaxue) algorithms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The doctrinal requirement for preemption and secrecy is also leading the PRC toward development of passive and active counterspace measures.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA is emphasizing passive counterspace operations in an attempt to deny foreign reconnaissance satellites with information on its disposition of forces and R&D programs.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Writings from the Academy of Military Sciences (AMS) indicate the PLA has a concerted effort to defeat opto-electronic, infrared, and radar reconnaissance systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese R&D into camouflage, concealment, and deception is explicitly intended to counter air- and space-based reconnaissance platforms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA engineers also have published technical papers on methods to reduce infrared signature of underground facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The GAD and China's electronics industry appear to be developing a jammer to counter radar satellites.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA affiliated publications assert that China is capable of damaging optical reconnaissance satellites through the use of high-powered lasers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC also is examining more lethal measures to negate foreign satellites, if necessary.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Open-source literature strongly suggests that a Chinese direct-ascent, anti-satellite (ASAT) program may be in the model development stage in which the space industry is identifying various design proposals for seekers and propulsion systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese writings indicate R&D of ASAT systems is intended to discourage attacks on their own space systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese engineers have also conducted studies to counter satellite decoys as well.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China currently can detect and track most satellites with sufficient accuracy for targeting purposes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA is modernizing and expanding its tracking network, which is operated by the PLA General Armament Department's China Launch and Tracking Control General (CLTC).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China Academy of Sciences' astronomical observatories in Nanjing and Kunming feed into the CLTC network, providing orbital prediction data.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's space community claims an ability to detect objects in space down to inches.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Phased Campaign A PLA theater missile campaign could take a number of forms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If the PLA indeed desires to deny US intervention through a fait accompli, a slow, gradual limited use option would permit a buildup of US forces in the region.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA operational concepts call for large-scale, preemptive operations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Strikes supporting the quest for information dominance would target the civilian and military leadership, semihardened command and control centers, weak links in Taiwan's defense information infrastructure, key intelligence collection facilities, and electronic warfare facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA conventional ballistic and land- attack cruise missiles would attempt to paralyze (tanhuan) Taiwan's command and control system by to cutting off fielded military forces from the civilian and military leadership in Taipei.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To achieve air superiority, the PLA would target key air defense sites and airfields.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA would seek to damage Taiwan Air Force runways, taxiways, weapons storage facilities, airfield command posts, and fuel depots to complicate generations of sorties.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To achieve sea superiority, PLA writings indicate prioritization of strikes against naval ports.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To maximize firepower for the most likely scenario, most probably would be based in the Nanjing Military Region or chopped to the Taiwan theater of operations joint command during a crisis.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA writings indicate that approximately percent of its total theater missile inventory would be used in the initial strike phase.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Western sources believe the PLA may deploy as many as SRBMs opposite Taiwan over the next several years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA officers envision a four-phase theater missile campaign: ) operational preparations phase (zuozhan zhunbei jieduan); ) campaign mobility phase (zhanyi jidong jieduan); ) missile strike phase (daodan tuji jieduan); and ) enemy counterattack phase (kangdi fanji jieduan).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese writings indicate that units intend to launch within minutes after arrival to the pre-surveyed launch sites.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To reduce reliance on pre-surveyed launch sites, however, the PLA appears to be integrating GPS onto their mobile launchers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA officers note the requirement to integrate the Second Artillery's automated C system with that of the joint theater command's automated C system.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese writings indicate that after an initial salvo, launchers could move to new pre-surveyed launchsites within that brigade's assigned area of operations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA intends to carry out synchronized launches from a wide range of azimuths in order to stress active missile defenses and associated battle management systems.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA has indicated prioritization of three target sets: ) air and missile defense sites; ) airfields and surface-to-surface missile sites; and ) command, control, communications, computer, and intelligence (C I) facilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA missile strikes against airfields could deny outside powers the ability to rush additional military equipment or military supplies to the island.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some PLA-affiliated analysts speculate that parallel strikes against airfields, air defense sites, and other critical targets could permit PLA air superiority over the skies of Taiwan in as little as minutes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA writings identify ground-based air and missile defense units as primary targets.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If no missile defenses existed, and CASC is able to meet the PLA's accuracy requirement of to meters, then only three to five missiles would be necessary to cause significant damage to key nodes within a fire unit with a high degree of confidence.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To neutralize active theater missile defense units, PLA writings indicate use of coordinated strikes from multiple directions, using a combination of ballistic missiles, decoy drones, land-attack cruise missiles, and/or antiradiation missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Another critical target for PLA ballistic and land-attack cruise missile strikes in a Taiwan scenario would be airfields and SSM sites.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA would need large numbers of theater missiles for a complete "airfield blockade."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, the PLA would need only a handful to impede Taiwan's ability to generate sorties.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Strikes against runways likely would be particularly effective in temporarily pinning down much of the Taiwan Air Force.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To aid in its training, the PLA has constructed a mockup of one of Taiwan's key airfields.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA could strike at the heart of Taiwan's political and military leadership to impede the command and control of its forces.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA has indicated a willingness to use highly accurate SRBMs, MRBMs, and LACMs against US assets, to include key bases in Japan and aircraft carriers operating in the Western Pacific.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese researchers have conducted extensive feasibility studies of the use of theater ballistic missiles against aircraft carriers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PLA proponents have proposed the use of GPS for midcourse inertial corrections and the use of a millimeter wave seeker for terminal guidance.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Aware of the vulnerability of millimeter wave seekers to jamming, PLA engineers are surveying ECCM techniques to ensure effectiveness of terminally guided ballistic missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition to aircraft carriers, other targets would include regional airbases, naval facilities, and key C I and logistic nodes, as indicated by Chinese writings.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For the counterstrike phase, PLA planners rely on survivability as a critical aspect of their theater missile force.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In ensuring their survivability, designers believe three systems in particular pose the greatest challenges to the survivability of China's theater missile force: the F- A, J-STARS, and AWACS.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese camouflage is explicitly intended to counter US air- and space-based reconnaissance platforms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An alleged arsenal of over SRBMs--augmented by additional conventional MRBMs and LACMs--could provide Beijing with a conclusive edge in a future Taiwan Strait conflict.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's growing presence in space is intimately related to the PLA's emerging capacity for theater strike operations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The same space-tracking network that manages China's space assets is crucial for operational security during a theater missile campaign.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Operational Implications China's emerging capacity for deep strike missions has a number of operational implications.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Consistent with emerging PLA doctrine of "rapid war, rapid resolution," a successful PLA theater missile campaign could strip Taiwan of its ability to effectively conduct air operations in a matter of hours (or minutes, according to PLA propaganda).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Strikes against key air defense units and airfields would result in a temporary suspension of Taiwan air operations, creating a more permissive environment for PLA Air Force operations over the island.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Furthermore, theater missile operations also could quickly degrade Taiwan's capacity for naval warfare and ground operations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Fifty percent of the PLA's theater missile arsenal is to be dedicated toward the opening phase of conflict.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Strikes against key bridges and staging areas would impede Taiwan Army counter-landing operations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Furthermore, China's expanding network of space sensors and long-range strike assets could pose a fundamental challenge to the US ability to project power into the Western Pacific Ocean.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Increasingly accurate and lethal theater missiles could raise the costs of US intervention in conflicts around the periphery of China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA clearly understands US vulnerabilities that arise from dependence on in-theater ports, airfields, logistic facilities, and C nodes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Successful fielding of terminally guided theater ballistic missiles could pose challenges to aircraft carrier battle groups, especially if operating within range of China's large inventory of -km-range SRBMs.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Taiwan has enjoyed a defensive advantage over the mainland for many years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Adequate warning time and a robust defense has enabled Taiwan to blunt PLA air, naval, and ground assaults long enough to allow the international community to adjust to the situation, decide on a course of action, take diplomatic action, and/or flow forces to the region if necessary.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A successful theater missile campaign--combined with information operations and air strikes--however, could enable Beijing to quickly strip Taiwan of its warfighting capacity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: To maintain the political and military viability of its new "trump card," Beijing has launched a coordinated foreign policy and propaganda campaign to shape the existing debate within the United States on defensive measures intended to counter theater missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing generally poses six arguments against missile defenses, including an assertion that defenses will cause an arms race.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Beijing's campaign against missile defenses exploits existing biases by some within the United States against missile defenses.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A mutually supporting dynamic exists between PRC officials and US critics whose views on missile defenses are founded on traditional nuclear stability paradigms.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Taiwan Strait case, however, may be unique in that it is the first theater in which highly accurate conventional ballistic missiles dominate the strategic landscape.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: PRC officials, echoed by many within US governmental and academic circles, argue that defenses against the growing PLA conventional theater missile threat would be destabilizing since they would spark an arms race.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The misplaced focus on missile defenses within academic and policy communities in the United States has resulted in neglect of at least three dangers presented by Beijing's growing arsenal of increasingly accurate and lethal theater missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, the conventional wisdom is that force would be used against Taiwan only in the event the government legally declares the island as an independent political entity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Confidence in a quick military victory could lower the perceived cost of conflict and thus increase Beijing's incentives to use force.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At a minimum, a decisive PLA advantage in offensive capabilities would increase risks of greater PRC bellicose behavior in the cross-Strait relationship.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, the ability to strip Taiwan of its capacity for military operations--in effect a first-strike capability--raises dangers of preemptive war.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA preemptive strike doctrine is also destabilizing since it decreases warning time that could allow for diplomatic intervention.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: An overwhelming offensive advantage may also reduce Beijing's incentives for arms control and confidence-building measures, and reduce their willingness to compromise in future cross-Strait dialogue.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, reduced costs for military action could lead to another unintended consequence of the theater missile buildup--a Taiwan punitive deterrent to raise the costs of PLA military action.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At least one punitive deterrent is Taiwan's own theater missile capability.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A Taiwan ballistic or land-attack cruise missile would serve as a political tool to raise the costs of PRC military action.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Even more ominous is that a severe collapse in its sense of security could prompt Taiwan to renew efforts to develop a nuclear device.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some think Taiwan has the capacity to develop nuclear weapons quickly if the need should arise.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Within the last two years, an open debate has arisen in Taiwan regarding the utility of developing weapons of mass destruction.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Third, as Taiwan's national security community debates the need for a deterrent, the magnitude of the theater missile challenge may increase domestic pressure for tactically offensive counterforce operations, to include preemptive strikes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As the PLA theater missile threat evolves, Taiwan strategists may adopt operational concepts outlined in US Department of Defense Joint Pub - .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This notion comes as no surprise to the PLA Second Artillery, an organization whose doctrine rests on the assumption that their phased campaign would be answered with Taiwan or US counterattacks.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The posited aim of a PLA air and missile campaign is strategic paralysis, with the expectation being that "paralysis" must somehow equate to "surrender."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: With proper preparations, Taiwan, or any other adversary, could recover from initial attacks.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Observers have asserted that Taipei would fold after the impact of a single missile on Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Taiwan could take steps to reduce the operational effectiveness of the PLA theater missiles and supporting surveillance assets.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The theater missile problem is already forcing the Taiwan military to modernize in a way that it would not have otherwise.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Assuming requisite changes and investments are made, the PLA's ability to achieve a decisive victory over Taiwan is not assured.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Passive defense includes: ) tactical warning; ) reducing the effectiveness of PLA targeting through operational security, deception, and mobility; ) reducing vulnerability through hardening, redundancy and robustness, dispersal, and effective civil defense; and ) recovery and reconstitution.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, the PLA's successful fielding of sophisticated terminal guidance systems would be accompanied by a new set of vulnerabilities.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: GPS, and optical, radar, and millimeter wave seekers can be jammed, as could the PLA's future space reconnaissance assets.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Exclusive reliance on active defenses, however, would be cost prohibitive and only partially effective against the type of theater missile threat that Taiwan is expected to face.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The most serious challenge to active defenses may be the tyranny of geography--Taiwan is close enough to the mainland to allow the PLA to launch from a wide range of azimuths.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In the end, however, the optimal solution lies in creating incentives for Beijing to moderate its theater missile deployments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The first step is recognizing the destabilizing nature of the PLA theater missile buildup.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although urging PLA restraint in deploying theater missiles opposite Taiwan is a worthwhile endeavor, we should not be overly sanguine about the chances for success.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Theater missiles are an integral part of the PLA's overall modernization objectives.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As long as the PLA seeks to develop the kind of force that could give the PRC a decisive military advantage over Taiwan, then the ability to freeze or roll back theater missile deployments will be limited.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Nevertheless, greater effort must be made to convince the civilian leadership in Beijing that the large-scale deployment of offensive weapons would adversely affect regional stability and that resolution of sovereignty disputes through other than peaceful means is not a viable option.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Key Indicators of Changes in Chinese Development and Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction Kenneth W. Allen

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The People's Republic of China (PRC) initiated its nuclear weapons program during the s as a result of its political and military rivalry with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since then, the Chinese Government has consistently used its nuclear weapons and ballistic missile technology as a political lever against the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China has become a signatory to several international nonproliferation treaties, this paper contends that in the future China will continue to proliferate nuclear weapons and missile technology for political and economic reasons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC Government has consistently stated that China's cooperation with other countries in the field of nuclear energy is exclusively for peaceful purposes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) spokesman stated, "The PRC does not advocate, encourage, or engage in nuclear proliferation, nor does China assist other countries in developing nuclear weapons."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A decade later, an MFA spokesman reiterated that, "China, as a responsible state, has never transferred equipment or technology for producing nuclear weapons to any other country, nor will China do so in the future."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since the s, Beijing has concluded agreements with as many as fourteen countries on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In response to international concerns about the PRC's proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) over the past decade, Beijing has become progressively involved in several international nonproliferation agreements and has promulgated various domestic export control regulations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During the late s, China and the United States clashed over conventional missile proliferation when Beijing began selling antiship missiles to Iran and DF- /CSS- ballistic missiles to Saudi Arabia.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: By the early s, the gap between the two nations widened as Beijing began providing DF- /M- missiles and components to Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As tensions mounted in the Taiwan Strait in late , Beijing issued its first White Paper on Arms Control and Disarmament.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The twenty-page paper, released during the negotiating endgame of the CTBT and while China was conducting nuclear tests, attempted to defuse concerns about a "China Threat" and accusations that Beijing was supplying weapons of mass destruction or related technologies to friendly neighbors (i.e., Pakistan and Iran).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In July , Beijing published its first defense white paper, China's National Defense.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: These two reports summed up China's commitment to conventional arms control by stating: China respects the right of every country to independent or collective self-defense and to acquisition of weapons for this purpose.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China practices strict control of the transfer of conventional military equipment and related technologies and observes the following principles: The export of weapons must help the recipient nation enhance its capability for legitimate self-defense; it must not impair peace, security, and stability of the relevant region and the world as a whole; and it must not be used to interfere in the recipient state's internal affairs.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In October , the Chinese Government published the Regulations of the People's Republic of China on the Control of Military Products Export.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has been consistently responsible regarding the transfer of missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is not a member state of the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) and has not joined its formulation and revision, but the Chinese Government promised to observe the guidelines and parameters of the MTCR in February .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In October , China reaffirmed its promise.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In line with the above policy, China has exercised strict and effective control over the export of missiles and related materials and has never done anything in violation of its commitments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China as a WMD Proliferator Despite of China's pronouncements denying WMD proliferation, the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) reported in August that "China was the worst proliferator of equipment and technology associated with WMD."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In , the CIA reported: China was continuing to take steps to strengthen its control over nuclear exports by promulgating new export control regulations covering the sale of dual-use nuclear equipment, as well as the export of equipment and materials associated exclusively with nuclear applications.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China also pledged in late not to engage in any new nuclear cooperation with Iran and to complete work on two remaining nuclear projects--a small research reactor and a zirconium production facility--in a relatively short period of time.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During early , Chinese entities provided a variety of missile-related items and assistance to several countries of proliferation concern.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese entities also sought to supply Iran and Syria with CW-related chemicals.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China has provided extensive support in the past to Pakistan's WMD programs, and some assistance continues.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This paper assumes that China will continue to proliferate WMD as a matter of official policy, regardless of what international agreements have been signed.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As described in other reports at this conference, since the early s, China has tried secretly to provide nuclear technology and/or missiles to several countries, including Pakistan, Iran, Syria, Algeria, North Korea, and Saudi Arabia.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's relationship with Iran also includes alleged cooperation on chemical weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The following work describes several driving factors within China's foreign, domestic, and economic policies for this proliferation activity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Foreign Policy Considerations I assume that China will continue to support its longstanding relations with Pakistan and Iran by providing WMD technology and equipment for existing programs, as well as for new programs in the future.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, an August Reuters article states, "China has signed an $ million deal to improve Iran's anti-ship missiles, raising questions about its vow not to supply Tehran with cruise missiles or related technology."

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC's relations with the Republic of China (ROC) on Taiwan also have been a factor in China's WMD proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During the s, the PRC's competition with the ROC for diplomatic recognition with several key states, such as South Africa, Saudi Arabia, and Israel, probably contributed to Beijing's calculations concerning its proliferation activity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Today, however, the ROC does not have diplomatic relations with any states of similar stature where the PRC could use WMD proliferation as an enticement to switch recognition.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although the Chinese Government still officially sanctions some proliferation with countries like Pakistan and Iran, it does have and will continue to have problems implementing and monitoring compliance from certain suppliers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The ring magnets, which can be used in gas centrifuges to enrich uranium, were sold for $ , by the China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC), a state-owned corporation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: In addition, although China and Pakistan were members of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the laboratory was not an IAEA- safeguarded facility.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As China moves further toward a market economy and defense-related state-owned enterprises (SOE) are required to sell more goods abroad in order to survive, they will be tempted to circumvent the growing list of export regulations and sell restricted WMD technology and equipment secretly to other countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Indicators of WMD Proliferation There are various macro-level indicators that can provide clues to China's proliferation of WMD.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's relations with the United States can be viewed as a barometer of Beijing's WMD relations with other countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Therefore, when Sino-US relations are on a downward trend, Beijing is more likely to circumvent prior agreements as leverage with Washington.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC's relations with Iran provide a good example of how China's foreign, domestic, and economic policies combine to promote WMD proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Initial relations in the early s were based on economic factors: Iran was willing to provide hard currency for technology, weapon systems, and the research and development conducted in China for new weapon systems to meet Iranian specifications.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since then, China's need for imported oil has been a factor in their relations.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Relations were also important domestically for China, as Beijing reportedly sought assurance from Tehran for Iran's non-interference with Xinjiang's restive Muslim population.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As United States arms sales to Taiwan have become more contentious during the s, Beijing has tried to link its arms sales to Tehran with Washington's arms sales to Taipei.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PRC often signs joint-venture contracts with foreign countries for weapon systems that are not necessarily intended for use within the People's Liberation Army (PLA).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: With the Iran-Iraq war providing a potential arms market, China began developing tactical missiles, such as the M- and M- , for export in with the hope that the PLA would become interested in the program later.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At that time, China had the technical expertise and facilities and was in search of hard currency, while Iran had the money but was not able to develop and produce new missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since then, China has reportedly provided complete M- systems, technology, and components to Pakistan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although this economic and military relationship was good for Beijing and Tehran, it conflicted with Washington's national security interests in the Gulf region.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China has denied the reports and has verbally agreed to abide by the MTCR guidelines, Beijing has not become a signatory to the agreement and allegedly continues to provide Pakistan with M- components.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: During the s, Washington's pressure on China and Iran to cease their energy cooperation has actually worked to strengthen the relationship between Beijing and Tehran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This pressure, which came at the same time President Clinton authorized Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui to visit his alma mater at Cornell, provided a backdrop for Beijing to increase its energy cooperation with Tehran.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Whereas China needed to import greater amounts of oil, Iran needed Chinese nuclear energy technology for civilian and military uses.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Moreover, the PRC has consistently tried to justify its military equipment sales to Iran by citing US military sales to Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Therefore, for all these reasons, China and Iran's independent relations with the United States, as well as complementary energy requirements, will continue to provide a good indicator of the continuing cooperation between Beijing and Tehran on WMD proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China's Five-Year Plan China's five-year plans provide the framework for the PRC's official political and economic policies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A careful review of these plans gives valuable clues about China's priorities in several areas, including military spending, R&D, and weapons acquisitions.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: For example, the current ninth five-year plan ( - ) identifies several areas where China can cooperate with foreign countries in conventional weapons and WMD.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The current plan encourages defense companies to develop military technologies for the PLA through joint ventures with foreign investors and to boost attempts to develop new weapons.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Owing to attempts to revitalize the defense-related State-Owned Enterprise (SOE) system and the PLA's R&D and procurement system, the Central Military Commission (CMC) has again restructured the entire PLA's weapons acquisition structure.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Determining which projects the CMC has decided to focus on provides one of the keys to analyzing which future weapon systems the PLA will receive and China will produce for export.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese open-source material often identifies various projects as focal points (zhong dian zhi yi), which means that these projects receive the highest political support.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA's Economic Situation Besides monitoring the five-year plans and defense industry economic indicators, the PLA's economic situation provides valuable clues as to military involvement in WMD proliferation abroad.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: At the movement's peak in the early s, PLA- affiliated businesses were estimated at about , .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: One of the driving forces was the PLA's need to supplement its budget.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As a result, several large companies, the most notable being the General Staff Department's Poly Technologies, emerged as valuable import and export arms of the PLA.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Some of these companies became involved in purchasing foreign military equipment and for selling surplus PLA equipment abroad.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Poly Technologies is best known for its sale of CSS- ballistic missiles from the PLA inventory to Saudi Arabia.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, Saudi Arabia actively sought out China's support.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Second, like Iran, Saudi Arabia was able to pay China with much-needed hard currency.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Third, China saw the sale as a way of pulling Saudi Arabia away from its diplomatic recognition of the Republic of China (ROC) on Taiwan.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This goal was finally achieved when the PRC and Saudi Arabia established diplomatic relations in July .

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Fourth, the PLA's ongoing modernization program led to the availability of the surplus missiles from its active inventory.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Finally, the PLA was actively seeking ways to accrue much-needed additional money to supplement its official budget.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The situation may be replayed over the next few years, following Jiang Zemin's ruling that the PLA must divest itself of its non-agriculture and industrial production companies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although the State Council has reportedly increased the PLA's annual budget, the PLA might seek ways to supplement this budget with further WMD sales abroad--either officially or unofficially.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Another indicator of official activities involves the use of military aircraft to transport Chinese delegations abroad or foreign delegations around China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: When transporting Chinese delegations abroad, these aircraft most likely will stop in various locations around China to pick up or drop off passengers.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If negotiations are handled through the Chinese Embassy abroad or the foreign embassy in Beijing, the permanent or temporary assignment of a new embassy official often provides an indication of ongoing, long-term negotiations and contract implementation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If the PLA is involved, the PLA may assign military representatives from the appropriate organization such as the newly established General Armament Department to the defense attache office.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This was the case when the United States had four foreign military sales (FMS) programs with China during the s. At that time, the Commission for Science, Technology, and Industry for National Defense (COSTIND) had uniformed military representatives assigned to the PRC Embassy in Washington.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Many Chinese ministries have established branch offices of their import/export companies in foreign countries.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The addition of new representatives to these offices or an unusual number of visitors from China provide indicators of negotiations or completed contracts.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Equipment Support When the Chinese provide any type of major equipment abroad, they also provide training and follow-up support either in China or in the host country for that equipment.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Thus, the continuing presence of large numbers of Chinese in key cities or weapons-related areas is a valuable indicator of on-going activity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Since the Chinese do not readily publish lists of key personnel or organizational structures, knowing who the key personnel are is often difficult.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Monitoring of China's ground and sea transportation systems also can provide potential indicators of delivery activity.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Because almost all of China's goods are moved by rail at one time or another within the country, unusual rail movements may provide important clues to the transfer of equipment.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As China's economy grows, competition for cargo space is becoming more intense.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA must submit requirements through the proper military and railway ministry channels anywhere from three to twelve months in advance.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese attendance at international symposiums provides a good indication of China's interest in certain technologies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Chinese hosting of international exhibitions and symposia enables them to agenda-set and invite foreign scholars and scientists who have information tailored to China's needs and interests.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Furthermore, hosting these exhibitions provides the most cost-effective means of obtaining information, since the Chinese normally charge foreign companies high prices for exhibition space.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Upgrading the PLA's Ballistic Missile Force There are several indicators for proliferation of WMD systems within the PLA.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: First, occasional articles in PLA and non-military publications, when added to previous information, unveil organizational changes related to impending or recent missile deployments.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: A close review of the PLA's organizational structure for the Second Artillery Corps provides valuable clues to the future structure of China's ballistic missile force.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: If China were to double or triple the number of ballistic missiles, as suggested in the Department of Defense report to Congress, the Second Artillery, headquarters for six bases, would have to ) increase the number of bases; ) increase the number of brigades per base; ) increase the number of battalions per brigade; and/or ) increase the number of reserve missiles.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The PLA has historically adhered to the "rule of three," which means that each division has three regiments, each regiment has three battalions, and each battalion has three companies.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although this rule is not hard and fast, it has provided the guiding principles for the PLA's organizational structure for fifty years.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: The Second Artillery appears to have as few as two brigades per base and as many as four battalions per brigade in some cases, but the PLA most likely would be reluctant to increase the number of brigades or battalions beyond four at a time when the rest of the PLA is shrinking.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Because the only real way for the PRC to radically increase the total number of missiles, other than increasing the number of reserve missiles, is to build more bases, an increase in bases would be a glaring indicator of missile proliferation.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Summary For political and economic reasons, the PRC is likely to continue as a WMD proliferator regardless of its acceptance of international regimes.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Sales of WMD technology and equipment abroad will be done officially and unofficially, involving the defense industry and the PLA.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Key indicators include changes in China's foreign and economic policies, especially as they pertain to relations with the United States.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: All of China's WMD proliferation activity has taken place in South Asia, the Middle East, and Africa.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Other than the possibility of war between Pakistan and India, the acquisition of WMD by the other countries would not directly affect China's security.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Therefore, monitoring of requirements by countries in these regions where China could fulfill some or all of their demands should provide an indicator of at least the potential for China to become involved in WMD proliferation there.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China is constantly seeking markets for its WMD technology and equipment.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: Although China might not be able to provide everything these proliferator countries are seeking, PRC companies, whether legally or illegally, might be willing to sell what they have available for the right price.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: This research focuses on China's nuclear arsenal, and does not address other possible Chinese weapons of mass destruction such as chemical and biological weapons (CBW).

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: According to treaties to which China is a party, the country is prohibited from developing, producing, or stockpiling CBW.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: China states that it "does not produce or possess chemical weapons" and that it "has never developed, produced, stockpiled, or otherwise acquired or retained biological agents, toxins, or weapons equipment or means of delivery for them."

Sentence: Relying on analysis of the ancient Seven Military Classics and Ming Dynasty ( - ) memorials on foreign policy which make frequent reference to classic Chinese strategic thinking, Iain Johnston shows that resort to violence, elimination of threats by force, and the imperative of offensive solutions were very much a part of Chinese strategic tradition.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: As Johnston acknowledges, however, the proclivities evident among Chinese strategists some years ago or more are not necessarily reflected in contemporary China.

Publication Title: 2000: China and Weapons of Mass Destruction: Implications for the United States
Sentence: However, he shows that, contrary to widely held opinion, there is a tradition of violent and offense-oriented strategies in traditional Chinese military thought.
